questions.text: 50-year-old Kim was having coffee in a cafe. After his coffee, he was feeling severe pain in his right leg. His vitals were checked and the blood pressure was 145/91mmHg, saturation was 95% and PR 87bpm. He has a history of smoking one packet daily for the last 30 years. No known previous history of hospitalization and diseases. Physical examination reveals that he got a pitting edema on his right leg extending upto the knee. His peripheral pulses all were symmetrical and full. He was admitted in the hospital and he was started with medications for prolonging activated partial thromboplastin time and prothrombin time in a dose dependent manner. But this caused no any effect in thrombin time. Which of the following agent would have been given to the patient for relief?
questions.solution:
The patient will be likely having a deep vein thrombosis. Heparin is required for the treatment of DVT, which can bind with the antithrombin III. Usually more than or equal to 3 therapies are needed to prevent the further thrombosis which will occur in the future. Drugs working on the extrinsic pathway will make the prothrombin time while drugs acting on the intrinsic pathway will be prolonging the aPTT. Factor Xa is a common factor for both the pathways. Heparin and other inhibitory drugs can prolong the thrombin time.

The main drug of choice for deep vein thrombosis is Vitamin K inhibitors such as Warfarin, direct factor Xa inhibitors such as Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Idraparinux, low molecular weight heparin and direct thrombin inhibitors such as Argatroban, Dabigatran. Among all these, direct factor Xa inhibitors are more specific that they will be inhibiting only Factor Xa.

Option A : They will be still in development. They will be working on the extrinsic pathway of coagulation cascade. As it works on the extrinsic pathway, PT will be getting prolonged than the aPTT and TT.

Option C : Direct thrombin inhibitors, they can prevent thrombin formation, which can lead to the formation of a new clot. They can make the TT longer with minimal activity on the aPTT or PT.

Option D : This can bind with the AT III. And will promote its action to bind with the factor Xa. This can make the aPTT to have longer duration. Heparin got a pentasacchride chain and it consist of more than 18 units. Thrombin also get bind with unfractionated heparin - AT III complex and it can also prolong TT.

Educational objective; Factor Xa inhibitors are having the specific action on Factor Xa with specific antithrombin activity. They can be used for increasing the PT and aPTT times. Here they will not be affecting the Thrombin time. Heparin can easily prolong TT.

questions.text: To control the bleeding from carotid artery, the surgeon can compress the carotid artery against the anterior tubercle of which of the following vertebrae?
questions.solution:
• The sixth cervical vertebra is a critical boundary of the root of the neck.
  • To enter the neck from the chest, the vascular structures pass through a ring like opening bounded by the scalene muscles laterally, the sternum and first ribs anteriorly and the vertebrae (notably C6).

questions.text: A fifty year old man with type-I diabetes is referred to an ophthalmologist for evaluation of developing cataract. Which of the following enzyme is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?
questions.solution: Aldose reductase is a general enzyme which can reduce any aldehyde sugar. This enzyme is the first enzyme of Sorbitol Pathway. When excess glucose is present in diabetics, then this enzyme converts Glucose to Sorbitol, which is responsible for Snow Flake Cataract.

questions.text: Richard and his son were walking towards their home after a cup of tea from outside. Near to his home he had an episode of fainting. And he was supported by his son to sit in a chair. Suddenly he lost his consciousness and woke up spontaneously after a minute. He was taken to an emergency department. The doctor ordered and electrocardiogram and it showed that the patient had a pulse rate of 49 bpm, regular rhythm and narrow QRS complex. There was desynchronization between P waves and QRS complex. Which of the following part inside the heart will be responsible for accelerating the ventricle?
questions.solution:
In myocardium electric impulses are generated by SA node. Depolarization start from apex to base and from endocardium to epicardium. Impulses comes to the ventricles through the conduction system. SA node can produce a heart rate of 60-100 bpm

On ECG the pacemaker location can be identified.

AV node produce a heart rate of 45-55 bpm. When there is an impairment between SA node and AV node, the AV nodal cells can act as the pacemaker cell.

This happens when AV block occurs. Here SA node causes atrial contraction while the impulses from AV node causes ventricular contraction. QRS complex will be narrow since ventricular depolarization goes in a normal way.

Option A, C : Heart rate will fall to almost 20 bpm as the electrical impulses are generated below bundle of His and AV node. In ECG we can see an abnormally shaped QRS complex since the impulses conducted through ventricles.

Option D : The heart rate will be normal electrical impulses are generated through SA node. In the ECG, P wave will be synchronized with QRS complex.

Educational objective : SA node is the main pacemaker of the heart because it has got the fastest firing rate. Only when the normal impulse conduction gets impaired, the other cells of the conduction system will come to act as the pacemakers.

questions.text:
Doctors of Washington University were having a study on membrane potential of human muscle cells. Many theses have been already submitted by the doctors. Now they are coming up with a study on animal. Due to ethics problem, neurophysiology doctors were about to conduct the experiment on a special animal called Giant squid. Experiments on frog was easily carried out and this was the first-time doctors going to make the practical on a Giant squid. Experiment was done and the doctors were able to plot a graph with the recordings of membrane potential with time.  
Membrane is mostly permeable to potassium ion and in which of the marked area will be having more permeability?
questions.solution:
The given graph explains the potential changes across the membranes along with the time. The changes such as depolarization, repolarization, hyperpolarization and resting potential are known as action potential. This occurs due to change in permeability to sodium and potassium ions. Stages of membrane potential are as follows;

Option A marked area will be the resting potential usually -70mV which is maintained by high resting membrane permeability to sodium. Potassium efflux need the non-gated voltage channels to make the transportation easy. The inner side of the membrane will be getting negative charged at the resting potential considering outer surface of the membrane.

Depolarization occurs during the opening of sodium channels with rapid inward movement of sodium ions as in Option E. This can lead to an increased positive charge inside the membrane. Maximum action potential happens when the membrane potential acquires a positive value approximately +35m as in Option A.

Repolarization, option C; Closure of sodium channel and simultaneous opening of potassium ions cause for the condition of repolarization. This can create a reduction in the permeability to sodium ions and a slight elevation in the permeability to potassium. Major factor causing for the returning of membrane potential back to resting potential is the outward movement of potassium ions. Hyperpolarization, as Option D, occurs because of the voltage gated potassium channel getting opened for a duration of short time after the repolarization got completed. Here the membrane potential will be less as compared to the normal resting potential and it will reach the equilibrium potential of potassium that is -85mV.

Educational objective; The rate of passive diffusion of molecules through the membrane is called the permeability of the membrane. Electric charge and the polarity are the main factors which are responsible for the permeability. Molar mass is also a factor responsible for the permeability.

questions.text: In New-York medical school during morning rounds a resident was suddenly found to be sweating a lot and he was telling that he is having palpitations and he was panicked and her blood pressure was found to be 160/90. He is 27 years aged and had a history of Type 1 DM since last 5 years. And his insulin regimen was stable for last 6 months. His friend told that just now he had a cup of water with little honey dissolved in it. And also, he added all these symptoms started after he drank that cup of water with honey. Which of the following can be a cause for his presentation?
questions.solution:
Typical symptoms of hypoglycemia include palpitations, confusion, sweating, tremor. Honey water or any sort of carbohydrate intake can encourage these symptoms. Exercise can lower blood sugar both in diabetic and non-diabetic people, therefore it is a main reason for hypoglycemia in diabetics.

Exercise affect glucose uptake in muscles in 2 ways. One is increase insulin independent uptake of glucose into exercising muscles. The other way is by sensitizing muscle cells into action of insulin.

Since insulin is released from beta cells, in normal people it can be stopped when there is a drop in blood glucose level. Diabetics is not having this feedback since it is always treated by exogenous insulin and sulfonylurea drugs which can help in keeping insulin in a high level despite low blood glucose levels. Insulin which is circulating can raised to a higher level if insulin is injected to an exercising muscle and can lead to hypoglycemia.

Option A C D; During infection, pain, sleeplessness, blood glucose level can have slight raise. Increase in catecholamines can lead to hyperglycemia mainly in stressed people by decreasing releasing of insulin also by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Educational objective; Due to increased glucose uptake after a strenous exercise in a diabetic patient hypoglycemia can be presented and also due to the fast absorption of sub cutaneous insulin when the insulin injected to a limb which is regularly getting exercised.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands and her parents report that she is sensitive to sunlight. On examination, there is dry skin with hyperpigmentation and mild atrophy of the skin. Two lesions resembling basal cell carcinoma are observed on her face. Which processes are most likely to be defective in this patient?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments
Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA

questions.solution:
Option C: Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA.

  • This patient is showing characteristics of a condition known as Xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • These individuals have sensitivity to sunlight with extensive freckling on body parts exposed to the sun.
  • In addition to increased cutaneous sensitivity to UV rays of sunlight, they are also present with hyperpigmentation (freckles), skin atrophy, and dehydrated skin.
  • This is a fatal condition as these patients are prone to developing skin cancers very young.
  • Exposure to UV light can form a covalent bond between two thymine molecules leading to the formation of thymine dimers.
  • These dimers halt the replication process of DNA as they do not allow DNA polymerase to move past them.
  • To prevent this, a mechanism called nucleotide excision repair is present.
  • Certain proteins (i.e., NER proteins) recognize the thymine dimers and excise them from the DNA.
  • If the genes responsible for NER proteins are mutated, the thymine dimers cannot be removed, resulting in the accumulation of damaged DNA, which ultimately leads to xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option A: Repair double-stranded breaks

  • Double stranded breaks involve cut in both the strands of DNA.
  • Double-stranded DNA breaks are repaired via non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or homologous recombination (HR).

Option B: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments

  • The proofreading function of DNA polymerase III removes the mismatched base from the 3' end through its 3' to 5' exonuclease activity.
  • This makes sure rectification of errors and correct base pairing during DNA replication.

Option D: Removal of uracil from DNA

  • Removal of uracil from DNA is done by base excision repair.
  • Mutation in proteins involved in base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

questions.text: 50-year-old Mark and his wife Esther was working in a multinational company. For the past few weeks Mark was feeling of general tiredness. He was not having any previous history. He also started with daytime sleepness and fatigue in the day time. He was taken to a physician and her wife also added that he was having a loud snoring in his sleep. Also, sometimes Mark has a break in his breathing. The doctor ordered him for a chest x-ray and a spirometry test. The most likely diagnosis for the patient can be;
questions.solution:
This patient has got the symptoms for recurrent nocturnal upper airway obstruction and apnea which can further lead to the obstructive sleep apnea syndrome. Each nocturnal episode causes transient hypercapnia and hypoxemia. This can be caused by reduced ventilation in the patient with obstructive sleep apnea. This can also result in the reflexive systemic and pulmonary vasoconstriction. Sympathetic cardiac stimulation can also be caused due to this. Untreated sleep apnea can further lead to the right heart failure too.

Systemic hypertension can be gradually developed in more than 50% of the patients with the obstructive sleep apnea. It can be considered as the result of stimulation of chronic cardiovascular stimulation and the increased level of norepinephrine.

Since 70% of the patients with sleep apnea have a BMI of more than 30kg/m2. Obesity can also contribute for this relation between sleep apnea and systemic hypertension.

Option B, C, D : Acute asthma can be accelerated by various factors that affecting on the upper respiratory tracts. Mainly such as the allergen exposure or smoke inhalation or cold weather. Adolescents can be affected by the acquired bronchiectasis. Adults are also affected and will be mainly associated with infection impaired drainage or inadequate host defence. Laryngeal carcinoma can be associated with the smoking and also with the alcohol use. These all conditions are not associated with the obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: 30-year-old G4P2A1 Mary with gestational age of 13 weeks, healthy and has no previous history of diseases. During prenatal check-up, she was ordered for a blood sugar, lipid profile and an ultrasonography scan. She presented with an elevated temperature. Her vitals were checked, and blood pressure was 117/79mmHg. Prior to this check-up, she had only multivitamin tablets. This time she was also ordered for an antipyretic drug too. USG reports also came to be normal. The blood reports came to be Glucose -215mg/dL and triglycerides- 234mg/dL. Triglycerides is an agent which can gradually lead to myocardial infarction. Which of the following substance can likely promote to Mary’s abnormal laboratory results?
questions.solution:
METABOLIC EFFECTS OF HUMAN PLACENTAL LACTOGEN

Profound alterations in the maternal metabolism can cause for the pregnancy. Metabolism of carbohydrate can be connected toward the glucose and to the fetus, aminoacids can be shunted. Here the mother will be getting the excess fatty acids, ketones and glycerol. This can be done successfully via placental hormones. One of the examples is human placental lactogen.

Syncitiotrophoblast is secreting the human placental lactogen, which go a structurally similar to prolactin and growth hormone. Maternal insulin resistance can be increased by hPL. This is helpful in reducing the maternal glucose utilization and elevate the blood glucose level by which it will be allowing the glucose to be shunted towards the baby. HPL can promote for the breaking of proteins and lipids, which leads to the condition of energy demand of the mother made up by free fatty acids and ketone bodies. This can also lead, to make the glucose more free to reach for the fetal use. Ketones can also provide the fetus with energy, in case if the mother had a malnutrition.

Maternal insulin resistance can, not only be occured due to the increased secretion of hPL but also due to the growth hormone, estrogen, progesterone, glucocorticoids production from the placenta. When a women’s pancreatic function will not be sufficient to overcome the increase in insulin resistance which is related to pregnancy will be resulting for the gestational diabetes.

Option A : This is responsible for the secretion of milk and the contraction of uterus. Glucose and the lipid metabolism will not be affected by this.

Option C : HCG is a hormone which is secreted by placenta. It helps in the promotion of maintenance of corpus luteum. This happens in the early phase of pregnancy. And this will lead to the release of progesterone. Progesterone can help in maintaining the secretory endometrium.

Option D : Thyroid binding globulin can be increased in pregnancy. All the free thyroid hormones will be in the normal level. T3 and T4 which are the circulating ones will be increased.

Educational objective : hPL has the ability to increase the insulin resistance. Breaking down of proteins and lipids can also be stimulated by hPL. Human placental lactogen can inhibit the process of production of new glucose. Resistance to maternal insulin can also be resulted from placental growth hormone, estrogen, progesterone and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: An enzyme catalyzing the reaction A + E → EA → E + P was mixed with 5 mM substrate concentration (compound A). The initial rate of formation of the product was 25% of Vmax. What is the Km value for the enzyme?
questions.solution:
Option D: 15 mM

  • This problem can be solved using the Michaelis–Menten equation.
  • Michaelis–Menten equation: V= (Vmax x [S]) / ([S] + Km)

Where,

V = velocity of the reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity

S = Substrate concentration

Km= Michaelis constant

Given that, the velocity (v) = 25% of Vmax, and substrate concentration [S] = 5 mM

So, 25% Vmax = (Vmax × 5)/ (Km + 5)

Or, ¼ = 5/(Km + 5)                                   [as 25% = ¼]

Or, Km + 5 = 20

Or, Km = 20-5

 So, Km = 15mM

The Michaelis-Menten kinetic equation is one of the best-known formulas of enzyme kinetics.

It can determine the kinetics of enzyme-controlled reactions, where the biochemical reaction is supposed to be including a single substrate.

Option A, B and C: Refer to explanation of D

questions.text: 45-year-old Tyson was a national weightlifter who has got many medals for Ghana. After getting selected for the world championship, Tyson moved to Russia for the world championship. There he was quarantined for a period of 15 days. After 15 days his covid test was negative and he also got all other regular check-ups. He got his blood pressure 140/80mmHg, PR was 101bpm. Blood counts was all in a normal range. The weight Tyson had to lift was 180kg (396lbs). His coach ensured that he was fit for the trials before the competition. During his first trials, he was able to hold the weight above his head for 5 to 6 seconds. But suddenly he drops the weight involuntarily. Which of the following may be responsible for this drop of weight from his hand in a sudden manner?
questions.solution:
Organs of golgi tendon are located in the junctions of the muscle and tendon. These are innervated by group 1b sensory axons. Golgi tendon organs are connected with extrafusal skeletal muscle fibres which are contracting. Its connected in a series way. Extrafusal muscle fibres are the muscle fibres which are innervated by alpha motor neurons and they contract and generate the tension and that will be allowing the movement of the skeletal muscles.

Inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord get in contact with the group 1b sensory axons which will be synapsing the alpha motor neurons which can innervate to the same muscle. For the maintenance of muscle tension golgi tendon circuit will be acting as a negative feedback system. Golgi tendon organs will stop the contractions of the muscle, when a muscle exerts too much force and that can cause for the sudden relaxation of muscles.

Option B and D; Pacinian corpuscles are mainly located in the subcutaneous tissues on the skin. They are also located on the mesentry, peritoneum and capsules in the joint. Pacinian cells are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors and Ruffini’s cells are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors. Ruffini’s end organs are also present in skin, subcutaneous tissue. Sensations of touch, proprioception and vibratory sensations will be innervating by myelinated A beta fibres. Both pacinian and ruffini’s cells help to mediate this.

Option C; Muscle spindles are connected in parallel with extrafusal fibres in contrast golgi tendon organs will be connected in the series way. They will be innervated by group Ia and group II sensory axons. This will be very much sensitive on the change of length in muscle. Stretch reflexes are mediated by muscle spindles. In most of the neurological examinations myotatic reflux is being tested.

Educational objective; Feedback system used for monitoring and maintaining the muscle length is the muscle spindle system while the muscle force is maintained by golgi tendon system. GTOs will not be responsive to touch or proprioception but they will be sensitive to increase in muscle tension.

questions.text: A 3-day-old boy who was born in the 32nd week of pregnancy suffers from respiratory distress syndrome. Doctors diagnose a heart murmur characteristic of an patent ductus arteriosus, a diagnosis that is confirmed by an echocardiogram. Which embryonic structure is involved in this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• PDA ( Patent ductus arteriosus ) is a condition in which, a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus connects Aorta and Pulmonary artery, allows blood to bypass the baby’s lungs before birth, fails to normally close after birth.
    • Ductus arteriosus is derived from the distal part of the left sixth aortic arch.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presented with history of abdominal distension. Initial investigations revealed mild anemia. Ct-scan revealed retroperitoneal fibrosis secondary pancreatic cyst. This retroperitoneal fibrosis commonly leads to:
questions.solution:
RETROPERITONEAL FIBROSIS

Causes: Mnemonic:

MILD

  • Malignancy(retroperitoneal)
  • Idiopathic ( most common)
  • Leaking aortic aneurysm
  • Drug related

Clinical presentation:

  • Backache
  • Onset of anuria
  • Renal failure

Investigations :

  • Hydrocephalus on CT

questions.text: 7-years-old Mike was taken to the pediatrician by his parents. They complained that, instead of going out and playing with other children their son is always remaining back in their home. And recently they also noticed that their son was feeling some difficulty in walking too. After a primary set of analgesic management, the problem was not getting solved. So that during the review of the patient, the physical examination revealed that Mike had a weakness in the lower extremity muscles. The doctor ordered for a biopsy from the calf muscle and the report came to be as shown in the figure. Which of the marked region contains thick filaments?
questions.solution:
Myosin- thick filaments are present only in the H band region of the sarcomere. It is a portion of A band and sharing with M line. Whole thick myosin filament is corresponded by A band which includes the portions which have been overlapped by thin actin filaments. During the time of contraction, by decreasing the size of H band, actin filaments will be sliding over the myosin filaments towards the M line. Contracted sarcomere has been shown in the given micrograph. On the contracted sarcomere H band will be narrower, with lucent over either side of the M line.

Option A : This is the area were cross connections are there which can hold the actin thin filaments in a proper manner.

Option B : Only actin thin filaments are contained in this part of I band. I band and H band both will get decreased during contraction.

Option C : This is the part that corresponds to the myosin thick filaments. This is part of A band in the sarcomere. Both myosin filaments will be overlapped with thin filaments of actin in this region. Also, non-overlapped myosin filaments are also seen here. This band will not be getting shortened during contraction.

Educational objective; Myosin thick filaments are present only in the H band region of the sarcomere. Region were myosin thick filaments are not having any overlapping thin filaments is the part of A band on either side of M line.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female was talking with her friends in a park in the morning. Suddenly she was fainted and feeling some confusion and was brought to the emergency room. Her vitals came to be, blood pressure 100/70mmhg. GCS score was 14. Her mother told that recently she has been drinking more amount of water and daily she has been going to toilet for more times and increased appetite. Also, the patient complained that she had a fruity smell in her breathe. Patient is undergoing in deficiency of certain substance that normally:

choices.text: Increases renal threshold for glucose reabsorption

questions.solution:
Patient has the classic symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis. DKA can come as a result of diabetic mellitus which is not yet diagnosed. Initial presentation of DM can be DKA mainly in people without regular health check-up.

Polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, these are the 3 main cardinal signs of DM. Deficiency of insulin and excess of glucagon along with adrenergic activation and increased level of cortisol and growth hormone. People who are already with diabetics cannot synthesize sufficient amount of insulin and to inhibit glucagon’s effect. Insulin will inhibit actions of glucagon.

In patients with DM and DKA glucose is easily passed on to the cells and the body can notice a sign of hypoglycemia and a state of starvation despite high serum glucose level. In adipose tissue ketoacid synthesis can be stimulated by glucagon because instead of glucose, ketoacids can be used by the cells for the energy during starvation. Glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, lipolysis and urea production can be increased by glucagon.

Signs of DKA include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, tachycardia, tachypnoea, lethargy.

Option A : Insulin does not affect the process of glomerular filtration in which glucose filtered from blood in glomerular capillaries in bowman’s capsule which is then collected in PCT.

Option D : Increased glucose in blood, increased amino acid concentration, cholecystokinin, acetyl choline, these all factors can increase glucagon secretion.

Educational Objective; glucagon actions are opposed by insulin. List of process which glucagon stimulate is gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, lipolysis, amino acid and potassium uptake by cells, lipolysis and ketone body production while insulin increases glucose uptake.

questions.text: A 64-year-old female was advised to get PET scan for her oncology evaluation. Which of the following is the tracer material used in PET scan?
questions.solution: 18-Flouro deoxy glucose (FDG) is glucose molecule labelled with positron emitting 18F. On administration, FDG enters inside the cell via GLUT-1 and phosphorylated by hexokinase to 18FDG phosphate. But, it can’t undergo further metabolism like glucose. Hence, it is effectively trapped inside the cell and release positrons which can be measured by radioactivity trackers.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presented with complaints of coughing & dysphagia for 1 week duration. You are auscultating the patient to rule out esophageal dysmotility. TRUE about boundary of triangle of auscultation is:
questions.solution:
Triangle of auscultation helps in hearing breath sounds clearly and splash sound of food entering stomach.

The triangle is formed by:

  • Trapezius - medial border
  • Lattismus Dorsii - lower border and
  • Scapula- lateral border

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presented with a 2 week history of swelling around the eyes & both legs and generalized body sweeling. After thoorogh evaluation, she was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. In such patients with nephrotic syndrome,edema is due to:
questions.solution:
Hypoalbuminemia

  • Albumin is the most abundant plasma protein and the size is just 69 kilodalton. So, it contributes the maximum to the plasma oncotic pressure.
  • If the concentration of albumin is lowered, fluid will no longer flow back into the intravascular compartment.
  • The resulting accumulation of fluid in the extravascular tissue spaces results in edema.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy, from a first-cousin consanguineous couple with history of change in colour of urine to black on exposure to air was diagnosed with Alkaptonuria. Which of the following accumulates abnormally in urine in such patients?
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria

  • Defect in catabolism of Tyrosine and Phenylalanine.
  • Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase.
  • Urine turns black on exposure to air due to oxidation of homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine.
  • Dark staining of diapers
  • Deposition of black pigments (polymerization of homogentisic acid occurring in body over years) in joints, cartilage and collagenous tissue, known as ochronosis. First pigment gets deposited in sclera, ear and nose cartilage, intervertebral discs, joints (ochronotic arthritis).
  • Later knee, shoulders, hips are also affected (small joints of hands and feet are spared)

DEPOSITION OF BLACK PIGMENTS ADDITIONAL EDGE ON THIS TOPIC

CATABOLISM OF PHENYLALANINE AND TYROSINE

questions.text: A 59-year-old male presents to the emergency department with the symptoms of urinary urgency, hesitancy, and the feeling of bladder fullness. The physician notes an enlarged prostate on digital rectal examination. Following a core needle biopsy, he is diagnosed with prostate cancer. Into which of the following structures do the prostatic ducts open?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostatic sinus

  • The prostate is a conical-shaped gland lying at the junction of the bladder and the penis. 
  • It has a base and an apex. It surrounds the upper part of the urethra, known as the prostatic urethra. 
  • The prostate secretes proteolytic enzymes that help in keeping the fluid consistency of the semen by preventing clotting.
  • Ducts from the prostate gland open into the Prostatic Sinus, which is a groove on either side of the urethral crest. These secretions then drain into the prostatic urethra through ducts of the glandular elements of the prostate.
  • The prostate gland receives the ejaculatory duct, which opens into the prostatic urethra on the seminal colliculus (a prominent elevation of the urethral crest) just lateral to the prostatic utricle, which is a small blind pouch.
  • The bulbourethral gland lies on the lateral side of the membranous urethra within the deep perineal pouch, but its duct opens into the bulbous portion of the spongy (penile) urethra.

 

Fig: Anatomy of the prostate.

Option A: Membranous part of the urethra

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the membranous part of the urethra.
  • The membranous part of the urethra lies outside the prostate.

Option B: Seminal colliculus  

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the seminal colliculus.
  • The seminal colliculus is just a prominent elevation of the urethral crest.

Option C: Spongy urethra

  • The prostatic ducts do not open into the spongy urethra.
  • The spongy urethra lies outside the prostate and is the penile part of the urethra.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient was referred by the family doctor to a tertiary Hospital. Patient had a complaint severe abdominal pain. His ultrasonography couldn’t find any abnormalities. He was advised for a gastro endoscopy by his surgeon on next day. His endoscopic study showed an early invasive cancer and the oncologists suggested for a total gastrectomy. The patient was advised for a lifelong supplementation of?
questions.solution:
Stomach performs a number of functions. Absorption of Vitamin B12, it needs intrinsic factors secreted from parietal cells. Patients with total gastrectomy done has to get lifelong supplementation of Vitamin B12 parenterally.

The ingested food is first stored in the stomach. Since, total gastrectomy has done it can lead to the bolus syndrome. Bolus syndrome characterized by nausea, sweating, loose stools etc.

Enzymes produced in stomach, has got a lot of functions such as maintaining the pH, digestion etc.

Option A and D : Whether gastrectomy done or not supplementation of gastric enzymes and HCl is necessary for all the people. Digestion and absorption of proteins can take place in the absence of pepsin which is produced from chief cells.

Option C : Short chain fatty acids are absorbed in stomach and most of the fat is absorbed in the small intestine. In gastrectomy patient’s fat-soluble vitamins will be absorbed along with dietary fats.

Educational objective : Patients with gastrectomy done has to get lifelong supplementation of Vitamin B12 due to poor absorption that occurs with the deficiency of intrinsic factors. Deficiency of intrinsic factors can lead to megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: One enzyme can catalyze the same reaction on a group of structurally similar compounds. Which of the following best describes this statement?
questions.solution:
SPECIFICITY OF ENZYMES

Absolute Specificity

Some enzymes are absolutely specific. For example, hydrolysis of urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide is catalyzed by urease. Urea is the only substrate forurease. Thiourea, though structurally similar to urea, will not act as the substrate for urease. Similarly glucose oxidase will oxidize only beta-D-glucose and no other isomeric form. Thus, these enzymes show absolute specificity.

Bond Specificity

Most of the proteolytic enzymes are showing group (bond) specificity. For example, trypsin can hydrolyze peptide bonds formed by carboxyl groups of arginine or lysine residues in any protein

Group Specificity

One enzyme can catalyze the same reaction on a group of structurally similar compounds, e.g. hexokinase can catalyze phosphorylation of glucose, galactose and mannose.

Stereospecificity

Human enzymes are specific for L-amino acids and D-sugars. Fumarase will hydrate fumaric acid (transform) to malic acid; but the corresponding cis form, maleic acid will not be acted upon. Lactate dehydrogenase, acting on pyruvate will form only L-lactate, but not the D variety.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presented to you with ankle strain after playing a football match. You are evaluating the patient. In foot pronation, the axis of which two joints become parallel:-
questions.solution:
• Transverse tarsal (Midtarsal) joint is a collective term for the talonavicular (TN) part of the talocalcaneonavicular joint and the calcaneocuboid (CC) joint.
  • The two joints are separated anatomically but act together functionally.
  • During supination of foot, the soles face each other and there occurs inversion, whereas, in pronation, soles move outwards and is accompanied by eversion (TN and CC joint become parallel)

questions.text: A 29 year old male was brought to the Emergency after a road traffic accident. On physical examination, you notice that there is a loss of sensation of the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers. The likely nerve injured is/are:

choices.text: Median nerve plus ulnar nerve only
Median nerve plus radial nerve only

questions.solution:
Explanation: Loss of sensation of lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers is due to lesion of median and radial nerve.

  • Sensations on the palmar aspect of lateral 3 &1/2 fingers (including nail beds) are carried by median nerve.
  • Lateral 3 & 1/2 fingers (excluding nail beds) on the dorsum of hand are supplied by radial nerve.
  • Palmar and dorsal aspect of medial 1 &1/2 fingers (including nail beds) is supplied by ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with decreased mobility in his right arm. Physical examination reveals a winged right scapula and an inability to raise his right arm above the horizontal. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
• The serratus anterior, innervated by the long thoracic nerve, is responsible for stabilization of the scapula during abduction of the arm from 90 to 180 degrees.
  • When the long thoracic nerve is damaged, it is difficult to elevate the arm above the horizontal. This nerve arises from C5, 6, and 7.
  • Remember: a “winged scapula” is a classic clue for long thoracic nerve injury

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus came for regular follow-up & to get his maintenance medications. The activity of which of the following enzyme is increased in Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic situation is same like fasting or starvation i.e. catabolic situation in the body.
  • So, in Diabetes Mellitus, the activity of Catabolic enzymes is increased.
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) is an enzyme of β-Oxidation which is a Catabolic pathway. Therefore, it is increased in Diabetes.
  • Option b & c - Phosphoenol Pyruvate Carboxykinase (PEPCK) and Glucose -6-Phosphatase are enzymes of Gluconeogenesis which is a Catabolic pathway and hence increased in Diabetes.
  • So, answer is all.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child was brought to you for regular check up. The curvature of vertebral spine which can be seen in children of this age group is:
questions.solution:
A baby at 9 to 10 month develops a secondary curvature at lumbar region of vertebral spine. It occurs due to the baby trying to acquire sitting and standing posture at this particular age.

The vertebral column in adults has four curvatures that occur in the cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral regions. The thoracic and sacral kyphoses are concave anteriorly. whereas the cervical and lumbar lordoses are concave posteriorly (i.e., convex anteriorly).

The thoracic and sacral kyphoses are primary curvatures that develop during the fetal period in relationship to the (flexed) fetal position. These primary curvatures are retained throughout life. The cervical and lumbar lordoses are secondary curvatures that result from extension from the flexed fetal position.

The cervical lordosis becomes evident when an infant begins to raise (extend) the head while prone and to hold the head erect while sitting (begins at the age of 2 months).

The lumbar lordosis becomes apparent when toddlers begin to assume the upright posture. standing and walking (begins at the age of 8 months).

questions.text: A middle aged women presents with fissures in mouth, tingling sensation and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this:   (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Vitamin B2 , also known as Warburg Yellow enzyme.

  • Active form of this is FMN, FAD. It is involved in oxidation-reduction reactions.
  • In its deficiency, there is decreased activity of glutathione reductase, as this enzyme is dependent on FAD.

B2 Deficiency: Riboflavinosis--->characterized by:

  • Corneal vascularization (earliest sign of deficiency).
  • Glossitis – inflammation of the tongue (magenta tongue- characteristic)
  • Cheilosis – redness and shiny appearance of lips
  • Angular stomatitis (lesions at the mucocutaneous junction at corners of the mouth), leading to painful fissures
  • Seborrheic dermatitis – rough scaly skin because of desquamation

Option 2- Vitamin B1 – Thiamin Nutritional Status can Be assessed by Erythrocyte Transketolase Activity - Thiamin deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option 3-Vitamin B6 - The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by measuring the activity of erythrocyte transaminases.

-The active form of vitamin B6 is the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

- Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness and mental confusion.

questions.text: A 38 years old male deceased was brought to the Department of Forensic Medicine for post-mortem examination. The deceased died two days back in Dubai after falling in sea, while he was working over cruise. Cause of death given by Dubai authorities was – Death due to drowning after preliminary enquiry and without post-mortem examination. Then dead body was embalmed and handed over to his relatives for funeral procedures in India. All of the following are constituents of embalming solution except:
questions.solution:
• Ethanol is a preservative and can be used for embalming but is not the usual content of embalming fluid/solution. In its place methanol is used, which is cheaper and more toxic to bacteria than ethanol. Methanol also holds the formaldehyde in solution.
  • Embalming is the process of treatment of the dead body with antiseptics and preservatives to prevent putrefaction.
  • Typically, embalming fluid contains a mixture of formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, methanol, and other solvents. The formaldehyde content generally ranges from 5 to 37 percent and the methanol content may range from 9 to 56 percent.
  • Preservative is the substance added to destroy or inhibit the growth of microorganisms. It alters enzymes and lysins of the body and arrest decomposition — fixing the specimen in such a way that it retains its original structure with minimal alteration. Formalin is the most commonly used fixative/ preservative and less commonly used are – Ethanol/ Phenol.
  • Phenol is a powerful Fungicide.
  • Glycerine is used in the embalming fluid as a hygroscopic/humectant/wetting agent and decreases the loss of water of the preserved structures (maintains hydration). But it is not the actual preservative by definition.
  • Wetting agents lower the surface tension of water and facilitate penetration and distribution of embalming fluids through the vascular beds into the tissues.

questions.text: 8 year old female child following URTI developed maculopapular rash on the jaw spreading onto the trunk which cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation and tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option 1
  • Kawasaki disease (KD), also known as Kawasaki syndrome, is an acute febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. Clinical signs include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the whites of the eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.
  • Causes: No one knows what causes Kawasaki disease, but scientists don't believe the disease is contagious from person to person. A number of theories link the disease to bacteria, viruses or other environmental factors, but none has been proved. Certain genes may increase your child's susceptibility to Kawasaki disease.
Option 2

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Caused by Parvovirus B19
  • Children (fifth disease) - Slapped cheek rashes
  • Adults - Polyarthropathy
Option 3

1. Points in favor of Rubella are:

  • Maculopapular rash on the face spreading onto the trunk.
  • Rash is cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation.
  • Tender post-auricular and sub-occipital lymphadenopathy.

2. Rubella is a milder and more subtle disease than measles.

3. Postnatal rubella:

  • Virus excreted in oropharyngeal secretions and infection is acquired by inhalation.
  • Virus multiplies locally in upper respiratory tract & cervical lymph nodes ? viraemia, dissemination throughout the body.
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks, fine pink macules first appearing on the face and then spreading to involve trunk and limbs.
  • Enlargement of postauricular, suboccipital, posterior cervical lymph nodes.
  • Recovery within 3-4 days of appearance of rash.
  • Complications: Polyarthritis (adult women, thrombocytopenic purpura, encephalopathy, panencephalitis

4. Congenital rubella:

  • Virus can cross the placental barrier and infect the fetus.
  • Congenital anomalies/death of the fetus.
  • Congenital defects: deafness, cataract, glaucoma, microphthalmia, retinopathy, congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis), microcephaly, mental retardation, thrombocytopenic purpura, hepatosplenomegaly.
Option 4
  • MEASLES (RUBEOLA) VIRUS: Maculopapular dusky red rashes appear after four days of fever (i.e. at 14th day of infection).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • The tumours are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumour typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

  • Image on the left showing perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • Image on the right showing Perineuronal satellitosis.

Option A: Glioblastoma

  • Glioblastoma is a Grade IV astrocytoma.
  • It is a common, highly malignant primary brain tumour with one-year median survival.
  • It is found in the cerebral hemispheres.
  • It can cross the corpus callosum "butterfly glioma" associated with EGFR amplification.
  • It is of astrocyte origin, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) positive.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumour cells with central border areas of necrosis, haemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • It is a low-grade astrocytoma. Most common primary brain tumour in childhood.
  • Usually well circumscribed.
  • In children, most often found in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellum), but supratentorial can also be found.
  • It has a benign course and a good prognosis.
  • Histology shows it is of astrocyte origin, GFAP positive, with bipolar neoplastic cells with hairlike projections.
  • Associated with microcysts and Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew fibres)

Option D: Medulloblastoma

  • Most common malignant brain tumour in childhood.
  • It commonly involves the cerebellum and can compress the 4th ventricle causing non-communicating hydrocephalus causing, headaches and papilledema.
  • It can involve the cerebellar vermis causing truncal ataxia.
  • It can send "drop metastases" to the spinal cord.
  • Histology shows it is a form of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET).
  • "Homer-Wright rosette" (small blue cells surrounding the central area of the neuropil)
  • It is positive for synaptophysin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with history of fever & headache for 2weeks with intermittent vomiting about three to four times per day. He had a history of repeated falls due to abnormal jerky movements of his whole body. The routine blood examinations revealed no abnormality. An MRI of the brain revealed findings consistent with SSPE. SSPE is associated with which of the following infections:
questions.solution:
Sub acute sclerosing pan-encephalitis

  • Also known as ‘dawson’s disease’, Dawson’s encephalitis
  • Rare complicatiuon of measles developing 7-10 year after measles infection
  • Frequency: 7 cases per million case of natural measles

questions.text: A dead body is recovered with multiple gun shot wounds. On examination, Abrasion collar is seen in the entry wound. Which of the following cannot be determined?
questions.solution:
Abrasion collar/ring :

  • As the bullet strikes the skin, it first indents and then stretches the skin surface so that perforation takes place through a tense area which produces a rim of flattened reddish-brown zone of abraded epidermis, surrounding the entrance wound.
  • The abrasion ring can vary in width, depending on the caliber of the weapon, the angle and site at which the bullet entered.
  • A bullet striking perpendicularly will produce a concentric ring, and if the bullet penetrates at an oblique angle, the zone will be eccentric with the wider zone on the side from which the bullet came

questions.text: A 25-years-old male was brought to emergency department in agitated state. On history taking, he informed that he is taking recreational drugs and he last took it intravenously 10 hours ago. He now complains of vomiting, chills and myalgia. His pupil size is larger than normal. RR= 30/min Temp=39 degree C What is the most probable cause of patient’s condition?

choices.text: The patient has overdose of opioid
Patient is showing symptoms of withdrawal syndrome
These are signs of toxicity of MPTP
The patient is taking barbiturates along with opioids

questions.solution:
Physical dependence is common with chronic use of opioids, which is revealed on abrupt discontinuation as a withdrawal syndrome. Patient can present with rhinorrhea, lacrimation, chills, gooseflesh, myalgia, mydriasis, diarrhea, agitation, anxiety, yawning and hostility. With morphine or heroin, these signs and symptoms can start within 6-10 hrs after last dose and the intensity depend on degree of physical dependence. As this patient took his last dose 10 hours ago, he is showing signs of withdrawal syndrome (agitation, chills, vomiting and myalgia). Administration of an opioid at this time suppresses abstinence signs and symptoms almost immediately

A) Manifestation of opioid overdosage are shallow breathing, flaccidity, cyanosis, pin point pupil, fall in BP and shock. This is not the case here in this patient

C) N-methyl-4-phenyl tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) occur as contaminant of some illicit drugs, produces nigrostriatal degeneration and manifestation similar to Parkinsonism. However, history is not suggestive of its use in this patient

D) Barbiturate poisoning is associated with CNS depression and cardiovascular collapse. But, nothing in history suggest their usage in this patient.

Learning objective: Abrupt discontinuation of opioids in a physically dependent patient can cause withdrawal/ abstinence syndrome

questions.text: A T.V program wants to know how many people of the country are in favour of a particular political ideology. An announcement is made in the program and the viewers respond to the question through phone call or message. Which type of sampling method is this?
questions.solution:
• This is type of volunteer sampling.
  • The members of the sample self-select themselves for being the part of the study.
  • In other words it is not the investigator who approaches the participants rather participants themselves reach the investigator.
  • In this type of sampling the sample is restricted and non-representative of the country’s population in a way only those people are the respondents who were watching the program at that moment.
  • People who were busy in some other tasks could not take part. Moreover, the viewers are those who already have an interest in the ongoing topic.

questions.text: All of the following are Type B - Bioterrorism agents except
questions.solution:
Bioterrorism Agents

Type A

  • Most dangerous & easy to spread
  • Can cause panic & chaos.
  • Specialized health responses are needed

Type B

  • Less dangerous & less easy to spread-
  • Moderate morbidity and mortality-
  • Require enhancement of diagnostic capacity

Type C

  • New emerging infections [readily available]-
  • Potentially high morbidity & mortality
  • Can be engineered for mass dissemination
  • Anthrax (M/C used)
  • Small Pox (Most dangerous)
  • Plague
  • Botulism (Most lethal toxin)
  • Tularemia
  • VHFs like Ebola and Marburg virus
  • Brucellosis
  • Glanders
  • Melioidosis
  • Psittacosis
  • Q fever
  • Epidemic Typhus
  • Cl. Perfringens
  • Food safety threats
  • Water safety threats
  • Ricin toxin
  • Staphylococcal toxin
  • Hanta virus
  • Nipah virus

questions.text: You are a medical officer organizing programme for creating awareness on coronary artery disease in the community. In a population to prevent the development of Coronary artery disease, changing harmful lifestyles by education is referred to as:-
questions.solution:
Primary level of prevention:

  • It is action taken prior to onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur.
  • It signifies ‘Intervention in the Pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease / health problem'.
  • Modes of Intervention:
  1. Health promotion : Targeted at strengthening the host through a variety of approaches / interventions, e.g. Environmental modifications, nutritional interventions etc.
  2. Specific protection : Targeted at prevention of a disease through specific prevention.[eg-vaccines]

questions.text: Calculate AUC for a drug M, which was given as a single bolus dose of 50mg given IV . drug M has Vd 150 litres and elimination rate constant of 0.2 h-1
questions.solution:
As per the question

·         elimination rate constant = 0.2 h-1

·         Vd = 150 litres

·         single bolus dose = 50mg

·         Bioavailability(F) = 1 as the drug is given IV

clearance = K X Vd

=  0.2 x 150 = 30  

AUC = F X Dose administered/ clearance           

  = 1 x 50 / 30      

       = 1.66 mg.h/L

questions.text: You are an intern posted in community health center. You are asked to present the Indian statistics regarding Road traffic accident deaths. All of the following statements are true regarding RTA deaths except:

choices.text: In India, the rate is 17/lac population
In India, there is no child restraint legislation
In India, the maximum permissible limit of Blood Alcohol Level is 80 mg/dl while driving
The death rate is higher in developing countries than in developed countries

questions.solution: In India, the rate of traffic accident deaths is at 17/lac population. Though, in India, we have rules regarding wearing seatbelt and helmet while driving, drunken driving, speed limits, use of mobile phone, there is no law on child restraint. In India, the maximum permissible limit of Blood Alcohol level is set at 30 mg/dl, as measured by Breath analyzer test. The death rate due to road traffic accidents is higher in low and middle-income countries.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with diabetes and hypertension for more than 10 years has been recently diagnose with diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following is the most characteristic finding in such patients with diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Diabetic Nephropathy Three lesions are encountered: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and Nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Capillary Basement Membrane Thickening. Widespread thickening of the glomerular capillary basement membrane (GBM) occurs in virtually all cases of diabetic nephropathy and is part and parcel of the diabetic microangiopathy Diffuse Mesangial Sclerosis. This lesion consists of diffuse increase in mesangial matrix. Nodular Glomerulosclerosis. This is also known as intercapillary glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease. It is the Most characteristic finding of Diabetic Nephropathy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with complaints of cough & shortness of breath. Initial investigations were done. HRCT revealed features consistent with the diagnosis of Mucormycosis. Which of the following is/are the cause(s) of the said diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucormycosis is caused by zygomycetes family which is characterized by aseptate & obtuse angled hyphae

This family includes:-

  1. Rhizopus
  2. Mucor
  3. Absidia
  • Mucormycosis is also known as zygomycosis
  • Mucor infection is very common in patients of diabetes mellitus and patients having frequent blood transfusion

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman (G2P1L1) with diabetes mellitus delivers a child after 38 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is the most likely abnormality that might be encountered in this child at birth?
questions.solution:
• Tight glucose control in diabetic mother is necessary to prevent overstimulation of fetal pancreas during gestation.
  • Fetus exposed to hyperglycemia in utero may develop hyperplasia of pancreatic β-cells, → secrete insulin autonomously → hypoglycemia
  • Increased birth weight [macrosomia] is commonly encountered in offspring of diabetic mothers
  • The incidence of mental retardation is not specifically increased.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the hospital with a high fever, chills, inflammation of lymphatic vessels, and swollen lymph nodes. On physical examination, the left leg of the patient was swollen with thickened skin. The clinical diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis was made by the physician. All of the following statements are true regarding Lymphatic Filariasis except?

choices.text: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus
Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

questions.solution:
Option B: Intermediate host – Man

  • The intermediate host in lymphatic filariasis is Mosquito.
  • Man is the Definitive host.

Option A: Causative agent – Wuchereria bancrofti

  • The causative agent of lymphatic filariasis is Wuchereria bancrofti.

Option C: Main vector in India – Culex quinquefasciatus

  • Main vector in India is Culex quinquefasciatus.

Option D: Most common epidemiological method for detection – Thick film preparation

  • Thick film preparation is the most common epidemiological method for detection.

questions.text: According to which section, if a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding
questions.solution:
S 132 IEA - If a witness is forced to give an answer admitting his guilt, he cannot be arrested or prosecuted for it and it is also not taken as proof against him in any criminal proceeding

S 151 IEA – Court can forbid indecent questions

S 152 IEA– Court can disallow the questions which are insulting/offensive

S 148 IEA– Court to decide when question shall be asked and when witness compelled to answer: Lawyer may attack the character of the witness. Such questions are proper it they are of such a nature that the truth of the imputation conveyed by them would seriously affect the opinion of the Courts as to the credibility of the witness on the matter to which testifies.

questions.text: Based on the characteristic cytological findings (pictures shown below) in a 31 year old patient who underwent thyroid FNAC, identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
• Given image is of Pap-stained liquid based cytology (LBC) of FNAC material showing nuclear grooving, pseudo-inclusions & Orphan Annie eye nuclei (ground glass clearing) → characteristic to papillary carcinoma of thyroid.
  • Other microscopic findings of papillary carcinoma:
    • Papillary formation with fibrovascular core
    • Psammoma bodies [concentrically calcified structures]

questions.text:
A 60-years-old female patient was diagnosed with hypertension and started on some anti-hypertensive medication. She is here for follow up and her serum electrolytes are as follows
Na+136 mEq/L
K+ 6.5 mmol/L
Which of the following medication she was started on?
questions.solution:
ACEIs (Enalapril) are one of the first-choice drugs for treating HTN. Mostly they are well tolerated. The side effects associated with ACEIs include cough, angioedema, hypotension, hyperkalemia (as seen in this case), skin rash, neutropenia, anemia and fetopathic syndrome

A) Calcium channel blockers (Amlodipine) are another class of first line antihypertensive drugs. They are involved in CYP3A4-mediated drug interactions, but have no effect on sodium and potassium levels

B) Loop diuretics (Torsemide) are indicated in presence of renal insufficiency, CHF, resistant cases or hypertensive emergency. They also cause hypokalemia and hyponatremia

C) Nebivolol’s role as first choice in the treatment of HTN debated. It has no effect on potassium level, it is rather associated with bradycardia, bronchospasm, peripheral vasoconstriction, worsening of acute heart failure (Nebivolol NO-mediated vasodilation)

Learning objective: while loop diuretics and thiazides cause hypokalemia, ACEIS/ARBs cause hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 30-years-old patient presented to medicine department last year with paint in small joints of hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and started on methotrexate. Patient did not respond to methotrexate and was started on a different drug. Patient came to medicine OPD today with gingival hyperplasia. Which of the following drug patient was most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine (calcineurin inhibitor) is an immunosuppressant drug. It is used as second line drug in autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. It is often used along with corticosteroids and methotrexate to suppress acute exacerbations. It is associated with side effects such as tremor, hallucinations, drowsiness, coma, nephrotoxicity, hypertension, hirsutism, hyperlipidemia and gum hyperplasia (as in this patient).

A) Prednisolone (corticosteroid) has immunosuppressant and anti-inflammatory action. They can be introduced at any stage of RA. The side effects include- ↑ blood glucose, hypertension, cushingoid habitus, ↑ weight, ↑ risk of infection, osteoporosis, glaucoma, cataracts, depression, anxiety, psychosis. Long-term treatment ⇒ adrenal suppression; withdraw slowly on alternate days

C) Azathioprine (cytotoxic agent) is less commonly used in rheumatoid arthritis. It has steroid sparing effect. It is associated with side effects such as bone marrow suppression, increased susceptibility to infections, hepatotoxicity, alopecia and GI toxicity

D) Mycophenolate mofetil (cytotoxic drug). It is used as add on drug to cyclosporine and steroids in renal transplantation. It can cause diarrhea, vomiting) and hematologic (leukopenia, pure red cell aplasia) problems

questions.text:
Which of the following are used in the management of hyperkalemia ?

Insulin + dextrose
IV Calcium carbonate
Potassium binding resins
Propanolol
Hemodialysis
Loop diuretics

choices.text: Options a , b , c, e, f

questions.solution:
Option b : IV Calcium gluconate is used

Option d : Salbutamol is used which is a beta agonist NOT Propanolol [beta blocker]

MANAGEMENT OF HYPERKALEMIA

Treatment modality Mechanism of action
IV Ca2+ gluconate Protects heart used if ECG changes are present
IV insulin + 50% dextrose (glucose helps to reduce risk of hypoglycemia)Salbutamol Redistribution of K+ to tissues
Loop diuretics Dialysis Excrete K+ out of body
K+ binding resins [ mainly for chronic hyperK+ ] Reduce K+ absorption from GIT

questions.text: DNA can be transferred from one bacterium to another by a number of processes. Uptake by a recipient cell of soluble DNA released from a donor cells is defined as which one of the following?
questions.solution:
1. Acquisition of soluble DNA from environment and incorporation in its genome is called transformation.
  2. First demonstrated in S. pneumoniae by Griffith 1928. DNA must be derived from closely related strain
  3. Cells that can take up naked DNA are called as competent
  4. Transformation can be inhibited by DNAases

questions.text: What is the correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality?

choices.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Prospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study> Case-control
RCT > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study > Cross-sectional > Case-control

questions.solution:
The correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality is generally as follows:

2. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

Here's an explanation of why this order is commonly used for establishing causality:

  • Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs): RCTs are often considered the gold standard for establishing causality because they involve random assignment of participants to treatment and control groups, which helps control for confounding variables. By randomly allocating exposures or interventions, RCTs can demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship.

  • Prospective Cohort Studies: In prospective cohort studies, individuals are followed over time, and their exposure to risk factors is measured before the development of the outcome. This design allows for the assessment of temporality, which is a key criterion for causality.

  • Retrospective Cohort Studies: Retrospective cohort studies also examine the relationship between exposures and outcomes, but they use historical data. While they are informative, they may be more prone to biases than prospective cohort studies because the exposure information is collected after the outcome has occurred.

  • Case-Control Studies: Case-control studies are retrospective in nature and compare individuals with the disease (cases) to those without the disease (controls) in terms of past exposures. They are useful for studying rare diseases or outcomes but are less robust for establishing causality compared to cohort studies.

  • Cross-Sectional Studies: Cross-sectional studies assess the prevalence of exposure and outcome at a single point in time. While they can provide valuable insights and generate hypotheses, they are generally less suited for establishing causality due to their inability to establish temporality and the potential for reverse causation.

  • Option 2 reflects this general hierarchy of study designs for assessing causality in epidemiology, with RCTs being the most robust method followed by prospective cohort studies, retrospective cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies.

questions.text: Which of the following method of measuring maternal mortality obtain information by interviewing a representative sample of respondents about the survival of all their adult sisters (to determine the number of ever marrried sisters, how many are alive, how many are dead, and how many died during pregnancy, delivery, or within six weeks of pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Approaches for measuring maternal mortality ·

In the absence of complete and accurate civil registration systems, MMR estimates are based upon a variety of methods: 

  1. Civil registration systems : This approach involves routine registration of births and deaths. Ideally, maternal mortality statistics should be obtained through civil registration data.
  2. Household survey : Where civil registration data are not available, household survey provides an alternative.
  3. Sisterhood methods : Sisterhood methods obtain information by interviewing a representative sample of respondents about the survival of all their adult sisters (to determine the number of ever married sisters, how many are alive, how many are dead, and how many died during pregnancy, delivery, or within six weeks of pregnancy.
  4. Reproductive-age mortality studies (RAMOS): This approach involves identifying and investigating the causes of all deaths of women of reproductive age in a defined area/population by using multiple sources of data.
  5. Verbal autopsy: This approach is used to assign cause of death through interview with family or community members, where medical certification of cause of death is not available. Records of births and deaths are collected periodically among small populations, under demographicsurveillance systems maintained by the research institutions in developing countries.
  6. Census : A national census, with the addition of a limited number of questions, could produce estimates of maternal mortality; this approach eliminates sampling errors and hence allows a more detailed breakdown of the results, including time trends, geographic subdivisions and socialstrata

questions.text: A 45-years-old patient came to the hospital with shortness of breath and swollen legs. He was diagnosed with congestive heart failure and started on furosemide. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality caused by furosemide can precipitate cardiac arrhythmia if patient is started on digoxin?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia and hypercalcemia increase the arrhythmogenic effect of digoxin

Pharmacotherapy of heart failure (as in this patient) include diuretics, digoxin, vasodilators, ACEIs and beta blockers.

Loop diuretics (such as furosemide) inhibit the Na+/K+/2Cl- co-transporter in the thick ascending limb of renal tubule, causing loss of Na+, K+ and Cl- ions in the urine. This also disrupts electrochemical gradient that facilitates paracellular reabsorption of Ca+ and Mg+, thus causing excretion of these ions. Increased Na+ delivery to the distal tubule, particularly when combined with activation of the renin–angiotensin system, leads to increased urinary K+ and H+ excretion, causing a hypochloremic alkalosis. If dietary K+ intake is not sufficient, hypokalemia may develop, and this may induce cardiac arrhythmias, particularly in patients taking cardiac glycosides. Increased Mg2+ and Ca2+ excretion may result in hypomagnesemia (a risk factor for cardiac arrhythmias) and hypocalcemia (rarely leading to tetany).

Digoxin (cardiac glycoside) inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase of myocardial fibres, alters the driving force for sodium-calcium exchange and results in increased intracellular calcium which ultimately increases myocardial contractility. The major signs of digoxin toxicity are arrhythmias.

  1. Hyponatremia and hypocalcemia are seen with loop diuretics; however, it will not increase arrhythmogenic effect of digoxin
  2. Hypernatremia and hyperkalemia are not seen with loop diuretics
  3. Hyponatremia is seen with loop diuretics, but it will not increase the risk of arrhythmia in this patient. Hypermagnesemia is not seen with loop diuretics

Learning objective:

  • Overall, loop diuretics cause electrolyte abnormalities in the form of hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.
  • Digoxin should be avoided in patients on loop diuretics as electrolyte abnormalities caused by loop diuretics (especially hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia) can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmia

questions.text: Activation of PKG by c GMP In vascular smooth muscle leads to:

choices.text: Activating  IP3-mediated Ca2+ release from intracellular stores
Phosphorylation of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to inhibit Ca2+ influx
Dephosphorylation of phospholamban, a modulator of the sarcoplasmic Calcium pump, leading to a more rapid reuptake of Ca2+ into intracellular stores
Dephosphorylation  and closing  the Ca2+-activated K+ channel

questions.solution:
Activation of PKG by c GMP In vascular smooth muscle leads to vasodilation by-

• Inhibiting IP3-mediated Ca2+ release from intracellular stores

• Phosphorylating voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to inhibit Ca2+ influx

• Phosphorylating phospholamban, a modulator of the sarcoplasmic Ca2+ pump, leading to a more rapid reuptake of Ca2+ into intracellular stores

• Phosphorylating and opening the Ca2+-activated K+ channel, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell membrane, which closes L-type Ca2+ channels and reduces the flux of Ca2+ into the cell

questions.text: A patient with complaints of high fever, runny nose, white spots inside the mouth, and skin rash, presented to the OPD. The clinical diagnosis of Measles was made by the physician. Which of the following age group is most commonly affected by measles?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: 6 months to 3 years

  • The age group most commonly affected by measles is 6 months to 3 years.
  • The clinical features of measles include 
    • Runny nose,
    • White spots inside the mouth
    • Skin rash
    •  High fever

Other options

Option A: 9 months to 3 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option B: 6 months to 2 years

  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

Option C: 5-9 years 

  • Mumps is more frequent in this age group (5 to 9 years).
  • Measles most frequently affects children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years.

questions.text: A 60-year-old former lifeguard presents with several small, pearly nodules on the back of her neck. A biopsy of one of the nodules (shown in the image) reveals buds of atypical, deeply-basophilic keratinocytes extending from the overlying epidermis into the papillary dermis. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
BCC is the most common malignant tumor in persons with pale skin. Although it may be locally aggressive, metastases are exceedingly rare. BCC usually develops on the sun-damaged skin of people with fair skin and freckles. The tumor is composed of nests of deeply basophilic epithelial cells with narrow rims
of cytoplasm that are attached to the epidermis and protrude into the subjacent papillary dermis. Basaloid keratinocytes are rarely seen in squamous cell carcinoma (choice D) and are not encountered in the other choices.

Diagnosis: Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought in with history of chronic diarrhea for the past 2 years. Initial investigations revealed no abnormalities. Further evaluation revealed it to be cause of Giardia. This recurrent Giardiasis can be associated with?
questions.solution: Common variable immunodeficiency is associated with recurrent giardiasis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the physician with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and painful, stiff joints for one month. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice. Her vitals are within normal limits. Investigation findings include anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with increased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test is positive for C3d. The peripheral blood film is shown below. What is the most likely cause of this pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cold AIHA

  • This is the case of cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia (cold AIHA), in which the patient presents with complaints of chronic fatigue, cyanosis with bluish lips, and arthralgia for one month.
  • Examination findings of pallor and jaundice, along with the presenting complaints, indicate an ongoing haemolytic disorder mediated by cold temperature.
  • This is further confirmed by anaemia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased reticulocyte count on laboratory findings.
  • Positive direct Coombs test for C3d and marked agglutination of RBCs seen in the above picture on peripheral blood smear confirms the diagnosis.
  • Cold AIHA is an autoantibody-mediated disorder characterised by the destruction of RBCs by cold-mediated autoantibodies at cold ambient temperatures of 0–4°C resulting in abnormal complement activation leading to acute intravascular and extravascular Haemolysis.
  • Clinical symptoms result from binding IgM to red cells in vascular beds where the temperature may fall below 30°C, such as in exposed fingers, toes, and ears.

Option B: Warm AIHA

  • It is also an autoantibody-mediated disease characterised by the binding of heat-sensitive autoantibodies, instead of cold-mediated antibodies, to RBCs, leading to increased red cell destruction by phagocytes and reticuloendothelial systems.
  • This autoantibody reaction is usually triggered by body temperatures of ≥ 37°C/98.6°F, with peripheral blood smear showing abundant spherocytes.

Option C: Hemoglobinopathy

  • It is usually characterised by the abnormal structure of haemoglobin, which can be seen on peripheral blood smears in the form of sickle-shaped or rod-shaped RBCs, target cells with microspherocytes.
  • It includes haemoglobin C disease, haemoglobin Zurich, sickle cell anaemia, and thalassemia.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited disease resulting in impaired glutathione regeneration, leading to increased susceptibility of RBCs to oxidative stress like infection, various drugs, and consumption of fava beans. This results in episodic hyperproliferative haemolytic anaemia.
  • Heinz bodies (small inclusions in RBCS containing precipitates of denatured haemoglobin) and bite cells are usually seen on peripheral blood smears.

questions.text: A6-year-old boy was presented with a history of intermittent fever and constipation for 7 days which progressed to vomiting, neck pain, myalgias, and headache for 2 days. Initial investigations were done. The physician suspected it as a cause of enteric origin. For isolation of Salmonella,Wilson and Blair is used. Which type of medium is Wilson -Blair medium?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair is a selective medium for Salmonella.

It contains an indicator bismuth sulphite that gets converted into bismuth sulphide as a result of the hydrogen sulphide produced by the Salmonella.

The color of the colonies on this medium is black.

questions.text: A 35 years old patient complains of abdominal cramps along with profuse diarrhea. The treating physician wants to process the stool culture for isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the media is best choice for stool culture?

choices.text: Culture on TCBS medium and incubated at 37º C under aerobic conditions
Culture on Skirrow medium and incubated at 42 ºC under microaerobic conditions
Culture on MacConkey medium and incubated at 42º C under aerobic conditions
Culture on Wilson & Blair medium and incubated at 37º C under microaerobic conditions

questions.solution:
Option 2

Selective media (Butzler medium, Skirrow’s medium, Preston’s Campylobacter selective medium, and Blaser’s medium) are needed, and incubation must be in an atmosphere with reduced O2 (5% O2) with added CO2 (10% CO2).

→ Incubation of primary plates for isolation of C. jejuni should be at 42°C.
  • TCBS (selective) medium is used for V. cholerae
  • MacConkey agar (indicator or differential media) It differentiate LF bacteria from NLF bacteria.
  • Wilson Blair bismuth sulphite medium: It is used for isolation of Salmonella Typhi.

questions.text: What is the age of abrasion?
questions.solution:
Scab has amost completely peeled off which indicates age >7 days
