Healing of Abrasion

  1. Fresh: Reddish in colour
  2. By 12- 24 hrs: Reddish Scab is formed (the scab formation occurs due to drying of superficial blood and lymph)
  3. By 2-3 days: Reddish brown scab

questions.text: A 10 year-old girl presented with recent onset blurred vision, intermittent diplopia, 'black spots' in her visual field, and ataxia. After thorough evaluation & imaging, she was diagnosed with medulloblastoma. Which of the following chromosomal mutation is associated in such patients?
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma can be subdivided into the following 4 groups:

  • TheWNT type, characterized by mutations in the WNT signaling pathway, tends to occur in older children, has a classic medulloblastoma histology, and shows monosomy of chromosome 6 and nuclear expression of β-catenin. The prognosis is best in this subtype with 90% 5-year survival.
  • TheSHH type,characterized by mutations involving the sonic hedgehog signaling pathway, tends to occur in infants or young adults, tends to have a nodular desmoplastic histology and may haveMYCNamplification. The prognosis is intermediate between the WNT subtype and groups 3 and 4.
  • Group 3 medulloblastoma, often withMYCamplification and isochromosome 17 (i17q), tends to occur in infants and children, with a classic or large cell histology and the worst prognosis.
  • Group 4is characterized by an i17q cytogenetic alteration, classic or large cell histology, withoutMYCamplification, but sometimes withMYCNamplification. The prognosis in group 4 is intermediate. In general, isochromosome 17q signals a poor prognosis, and is restricted to groups 3 and 4.

questions.text: A 37-year-old married man presents with multiple blister-like lesions on the glans of his penis, appearing over the past 2 days. On questioning, he recalls similar episodes over the past 2 years. The examination is remarkable for tender, 3-4 mm vesicular lesions on the shaft of his penis with no apparent crusting, drainage, or bleeding. There is also slight bilateral inguinal adenopathy. During the asymptomatic period between outbreaks, where would the causative agent likely have been found?
questions.solution:
• Recurrent attacks of multiple blister-like lesions on the glans suggests genital herpes.
  • This is most often caused by HSV-2.
  • HSV are extremely widespread in the human population.
  • They are responsible for a spectrum of diseases, ranging from gingivostomatitis to keratoconjunctivitis, encephalitis, genital disease, and infections of newborns.
  • The HSVs establish latent infections in nerve cells and recurrences are common
  • During the asymptomatic period of genital herpes, sacral nerve root ganglia (S2 to S5) are the site of latency.

questions.text: Active immunization is considered as the induction of immunity after exposure to an antigen. All of the following can result in active immunity except:
questions.solution:
Adaptive immunity is of 4 types

  • Natural active (associated with infections)
  • Natural passive (from Mother to child through placenta or breast feeding)
  • Artificial active (Vaccination)
  • Artificial Passive through immunoglobin transfer

So correct option is ‘c’ in which active immunity is Not acquired through Immunoglobin transfer.

questions.text: A 60-years-old man came to the hospital complaining of severe pain, swelling and redness at the metatarsophalangeal joint of his left big toe. He has BMI of 34 with history of hypertension. Which of the following drug could be the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is showing signs and symptoms of acute gout. As patient is hypertensive, he might be taking thiazide diuretics (chlorthalidone) and long-term use of thiazides can cause increase in blood urate levels.

Thiazide diuretics inhibit NaCl transport in the DCT. Most serious adverse effects of thiazides include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Because of their tendency to cause hyperuricemia, they can precipitate an acute attack of gout as seen in this patient. Simple review of medication will relieve symptoms of this patient.

  1. Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker
  2. Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor
  3. Telmisartan is an ARB (Except chlorthalidone, rest of the drugs have no effect on serum uric acid levels)

Learning objective: Thiazides cause hyperuricemia, therefore to be used with caution in patients who are at increased risk for gout.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with complaints of watery diarrhea & abdominal cramps. The causative organism Clostridium perfringens was identified by the test as shown below.aIdentify the test?

choices.text: Example of agar diffusion in 2 dimensions
Demonstration of Swarming of C. perfringens

questions.solution:
The above test is Nagler reaction which is aNeutralization test .

Reactions of Clostridium perfringens:

1. Nagler reaction : It is a biochemical test used toidentify organisms (Eg: Clostridium perfringens) that liberate phospholipases (lecithinases). Bacterial lecithinase break down the lecithin (a normal component of egg yolk) to insoluble diglycerides resulting in an opaque halo.

Procedure:

  • The media used isEgg yolk mediumwhere Clostridium is inoculated in two streaks (one is of test organism and other is control organism).
  • On one half of the culture plate anti-toxin is added , on the another half there is no antitoxin.
  • Neutralization occurs between antitoxin and α lecithinase toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens.
  • An opalescent halo is formed around colonies that produce lecithinase (clostridial α-toxin).

2. Target haemolysis : Double zone haemolysis (Refer to the image below).

Inner zone: due to the theta toxin

Outer zone: due toalphatoxin.

3.Stormy fermentation in litmus milk.

4.Reverse CAMP test.(Image below)

questions.text: A 23 years old male working in an iron factory visited the hospital for taking his TT dose. Injectable tetanus toxoid (TT) is an example of which of the following immunity?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Active immunity

  • The toxins produced by organisms such as Diptheria & Tetanus are detoxicated and used in the preparation for Vaccines (Toxoids).
  • These detoxified toxins when administered in the body can elicit an immune response resulting in antibody production & memory.
  • Antibodies are produced to neutralize the toxic moiety produced during infection by these organisms thus providing active immunization to the body.

Option B: Passive Immunity

  • Passive immunity is provided by the transfer of ready-made antibodies.
  • The host body does not produce its own Antibodies.

Option C: Native Immunity

  • Resistance to the infection from birth by its genetic or constitutional makeup.
  • Depends on
    • S: Species-specific
    • I: Individual specific
    • R: Race specific
  • Components
    • Phagocytes (monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils)
    • NK (natural Killer) cells
    • Alternate complement pathway
    • Acute Phase Proteins (CRP, MBP Serum amyloid protein)
    • Normal resident Flora
    • Inflammation, Fever
    • Skin & mucosal barrier

Option D: Innate immunity 

  • Innate immunity is present at birth.
  • Examples: Physical barrier, physiological barrier, cellular barrier, and inflammatory barrier.

questions.text: A 65-years-old man presented to the clinic with a complaint of urinary incontinence. He was started on a new drug Mirabegron which is a beta 3 receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. All of the following is true regarding Mirabegron EXCEPT:

choices.text: It increases the incidence of urinary tract infections

questions.solution:
Mirabegron a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist approved for use against incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence. Side effects include increased blood pressure, increased incidence of urinary tract infection, and headache. Mirabegron is also a moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor, so care must be taken when prescribing with other drugs metabolized by CYP2D6, such as digoxin, metoprolol, and desipramine.

A) Mirabegron can cause rise in blood pressure

B) It is associated with increase in incidence of urinary tract infection

C) It is associated with adverse effect of headache

Learning objective : Mirabegron (β3 adrenergic receptor agonist) is a CYP2D6 inhibitor, so it can cause drug interactions with other drugs metabolized by CYP2D6.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man sustained fracture of overlying skull bone after involved in a motor vehicular accident. This finding is usually present with
questions.solution:
Epidural/ Extradural haemorrhage:

  • Bleeding occurring between the inner table of the skull and meninges
  • Least commonintracranial haemorrhage (10%)

Causes : Mostly traumaticin origin, andunilateral.

Salient Features :

  • It occurs usually on the side of the impact (coup injury)
  • Never a counter coup injury
  • Forms a circumscribed ovoid or disk-shaped blood clot

Age group :

  • Common in adults between 20–40 years.
  • Rare in the elderly and children due to greater adherence of dura to the skull.

Fracture (fissure type)is present in most of the cases

questions.text: The perinatal mortality rate includes both late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths. Which of the following is the correct denominator to calculate perinatal mortality in a nation with less well-established vital records?
questions.solution:
Option A: 1000 live births

  • The WHO's definition, For Nations with less well-established vital records,
    • PNMR = Late fetal deaths (28 weeks gestation and more) + early neonatal deaths (first week) in one year / Live births in a year × 1000
    • Because in the questions, the denominator for less well-established vital records nations is asked, answer A is the correct choice.

questions.text: A 25 years old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. You were the assistant doctor with your senior for the delivery. After successful delivery of the baby your senior asks you what is the ‘first immunization’ of the baby?

choices.text: Handing over the baby to mother

questions.solution:
Colostrum

  • Is the most suitable food immediately after birth of the baby; Regular milk comes 3-6 days after birth.
  • Aka ‘Beestings’, ‘First milk’ or ‘Immune Milk’.
  • High in carbohydrates, proteins, antibodies & low in fat.
  • Contain all five immunoglobulins found in all mammals, IgA (highest), IgD, IgE, IgG & IgM.
  • Known as ‘first immunization’ of newborn.

OPV

  • Oral Polio Vaccine / SABIN is a Bivalent vaccine (P1, P3 strain).
  • Dosage:
    • 1st dose given immediately at birth or as soon as possible, then at 6weeks followed by 10 and 14 weeks.
    • 1st booster: 16-24 m.
    • Another dose at 5 y along with DPT booster.

Handing over the baby to mother

  • Handing over the baby to mother is a wrong option.

DPT + BCG

  • 1st dose of DPT is give at 6 weeks after birth and 1st dose of BCG is given at the time of birth or as early as possible till one year of age.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented to the general OPD with complaints of colicky pain in the abdomen following a meal for 1 hour. She was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. Open cholecystectomy was performed. She was kept post-operatively in the surgical ward for a few days and given anticoagulants. Which of the following statement is true regarding warfarin?

choices.text: They interfere with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
These can produce anticoagulant effects both in vivo and in vitro.
These can produce bleeding like hematuria and cerebral haemorrhage
Their action starts immediately, so they are helpful for the initiation of therapy in deep vein thrombosis

questions.solution:
Option C: These can produce bleeding like hematuria and cerebral haemorrhage.

  • In this case, the 45-year-old lady presented with typical cholecystitis symptoms: colicky abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, worsened after meal intake. She underwent open cholecystectomy for the treatment of acute cholecystitis. Post-op care generally involves using anticoagulants, physiotherapy and compression stockings to avoid deep venous thrombosis due to immobility.
  • Drugs in the warfarin group, or oral anticoagulants, include warfarin, dicumarol, phenindione etc.
  • These drugs inhibit the activation of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. These factors include clotting factors II, VII, IX and X.
  • The onset of oral anticoagulants develops gradually over 1-3 days, thus used for the maintenance of anticoagulation.
  • Bleeding is the most common adverse effect of all anticoagulants. It can present as hematuria and severe cases, even cerebral haemorrhage.
  • Phenindione causes orange-coloured urine as well as hepatotoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

Option A: They interfere with the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

  • Synthesis of these factors remains unaffected.
  • The mechanism of action of these drugs merely involves the inhibition of activation of vitamin K-dependent factors.

Option B: These can produce anticoagulant effects in vivo and in vitro.

  • These drugs do not affect already formed factors, so these are not effective in vitro.

Option D: Their action starts immediately, so they are helpful for the initiation of therapy in deep vein thrombosis.

  • Since they affect only the activation of clotting factors rather than their synthesis, the therapeutic effect is gradual.
  • The first factor to disappear is factor VII (t1/2= 6 hours), and the last to disappear is factor II (t1/2= 60 hours).
  • They are therefore used for maintenance rather than induction.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:-
The term ‘disease control’ describes ongoing operations aimed at reducing the
1. Incidence of disease
2. Financial burden to the community
3. Effects of infection including both physical and psychological complications
4. Duration of disease and its transmission
Of all these statements,
questions.solution:
• Disease control primarily refers to ‘primary and secondary levels’ of prevention
  • Disease control’ describes ongoing operations aimed at reducing the Incidence of disease, Financial burden to the community, Effects of infection, Duration of disease and its transmission

questions.text: A suspect has been brought in for questioning and investigation in relation to a case of murder. He is accused of firing an unlicensed rifle at the victim at close range. The forensic team proceeds with the test shown in the image below. What is the test that is being performed ?

choices.text: Neutron activation analysis for firearm use

questions.solution:
Gun Shot Residues (GSR) on suspects hands

  • GSR on the hands may be visible to necked eyes can be observed and described.
  • If not visible special techniques can be used to demonstrate invisible GSR.

Various tests for detecting GSR·

  • Paraffin test (dermal nitrate test/diphenylamine test)·
  • Harrison and Gilroy test
  • Neutron activation analysis
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS)
  • Flameless atomic absorption spectrophotometry (FAAS)
  • Scanning Electron Microscope- Energy Dispersive X-ray spectrometry (SEM-EDX)

3. Neutron Activation Analysis

  • A sample is obtained by use of paraffin or by washing hands with dilute acid.
  • It is then exposed to radiation from a nuclear reactor emitting neutrons.
  • Secondary radioactivity is induced in the materials and by making appropriate counts at different energy levels, the elemental composition of the residues can be determined
  • Advantage: extremely sensitive
  • Limitation:
    • It can analyse only antimony and barium but not lead and thus had to be used with FAAS
    • expensive (need of nuclear reactor)
    • Was discarded by 1990s

questions.text: The ratio between the incidence of disease among exposed and non-exposed is called:
questions.solution:
Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by:

  • Relative risk (RR)
  • Attributable risk (AR)
  • Population attributable risk (PAR)

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/ Incidence among non-exposed

  • RR = Iexp / Inonexp
  • Interpretation of RR: Incidence of disease among exposed IS SO MANY TIME HIGHER as compared to that among non-exposed.

Attributable risk (AR) = Incidence among exposed- Incidence among non-exposed / Incidence among exposed.

A – III, B – II, C – II, D – I
A – IV, B – III, C – II, D – I
A – III, B – IV, C – I, D – II

questions.solution:
• Accuracy: degree of closeness of a measured or calculated quantity to its actual (true) value
  • Precision: the degree to which further measurements or calculations show the same or similar results; Precision is also known as: reliability, repeatability, consistency or reproducibility
  • Reliability is precision, while validity is accuracy

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl child was brought in with complaints of delayed development of growth milestones. She is also found to have decreased intellectual ability. Mental retardation is defined If IQ is below
questions.solution:
A child with IQ<70 is called mentally retarded -

The WHO classification of mental retardation is based on the concept of IQ and includes the following categories:

Category IQ
Mild 50-70
Moderate 35-49
Severe 20-34
Profound <20

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is due to paternal disomy of chromosome 15?
questions.solution:
Discussing the options one by one:

A. Prader Willi syndrome: Uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15

B.Angelman syndrome:Uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15

C.Hydatidiform mole: Contains a normal number of diploid chromosomes, but they are all of paternalorigin.

The opposite situation occurs inovarian teratoma, with 46 chromosomes ofmaternalorigin.

Note thatHydatidiform mole & ovarian Teratoma are also due to uniparental disomy

D. Klinefelter’s syndrome: 47, XXY

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension was diagnosed with Lymphangiosarcoma. Which of the following is the most common site for lymphangiosarcoma? is :
questions.solution: Most cases arise from lymphedema induced by a radical mastectomy in breast cancer patients with an average onset of 5 - 15 years and an occurrence rate of <1%. Although there has also been significant reports regarding development from Milroy lymphedema and in idiopathic, congenital, traumatic, or filarial lymphedema.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male with history of chest pain and poolyarthrisitis was diagnosed with Acute Rheumatic Fever. Which of the following is the mechanism for development of ARF?

choices.text: Due to toxin secretion by streptococci

questions.solution: Acute rheumatic fever results from immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. pyogenes) which cross-reacts with host tissues. The antibodies directed against the M proteins of streptococci cross react with the self antigens in the heart. In addition, CD4+ T cells specific for streptococcal peptides also react with self proteins in the heart and produce macrophage activating cytokines. So, the damage to the heart tissue is a combination of antibody and T-cell mediated reactions.

questions.text: An elderly multiparous women with intrauterine foetal death was admitted with strong labour pains. The patient suddenly goes in shock with cyanosis, respiratory disturbances and pulmonary oedema. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism

Diagnostic Criteria for Amnionic Fluid Embolism:

  • Abrupt onset of cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise. Documentation of overt disseminated intravascular coagulation.
  • Coagulopathy must be detected prior to loss of sufficient blood to cause dilutional or shock- related consumptive coagulopathy.
  • Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of placental delivery.
  • No fever ≥38°C.

Predisposing conditions

  • Rapid labor
  • Meconium stained fluid
  • Tears in uterine and other large pelvic veins that permits exchange of fluids between maternal and fetal compartments
  • Labour induction or augmentation
  • Placental abruption

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of fall and on X ray is detected with a spinal vertebral fracture. On neuro-examination the doctor finds that the pain and temperature sensations on the opposite side of the body, distal to the injury are absent. Which spinal pathway has been distrupted?
questions.solution:
Ascending and Descending (Motor) Tracts
Number Path Function Side of Body
1 Anterior corticospinal tract Skilled movement Opposite
2 Vestibulospinal tract Facilitates extensor muscle tone Same
3 Lateral corticospinal (Pyramidal tract) Skilled movement Same
4 Dorsolateral fasciculus Pain and temperature Bidirectional
5 Fasciculus proprius Short spinal connections Bidirectional
6 Fasciculus gracilis Position/ fine touch Same
7 Fasciculus cuneatus Position/ fine touch Same
8 Lateran spinothalamic tract Pain and temperature Opposite
9 Anterior spinothalamic tract Light touch Opposite

Learning objective : Knowledge of the pathways of the spinal cord will make one diagnose the location of pathology on a simple neurological assessment. Combined with radiology it helps a doctor to properly diagnose and manage a patient.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented with clinical features of Acute Myeloid Leukemia in peripheral blood smear. Initial investigation revealed leukostasis. Which organ is mainly affected in patients with Hyperleukocytosis - Leukostasis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lung

  • The brain and Lungs are the most commonly affected organs (44% and 36%, respectively) by hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome.
  • WBC counts more than 100,000/cu.mm lead to leukostasis plugging of the capillaries followed by endothelial damage to blood vessels.
  • The presence of dyspnea, tachypnea and respiratory distress indicate pulmonary leukostasis.
  • C.N.S. leukostasis presents with stupor, headache and dizziness.
  • The mortality occurs due to respiratory failure, intracranial haemorrhage and coma.
  • The low PO2 is due to increased consumption of oxygen by leucocytes.

Option A: Liver

  • Involvement of liver/G.I. in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 3%

Option B: Heart

  • Involvement of heart (myocardial infarction) in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 6%

Option C: Kidney

  • Involvement of kidneys in hyperleukocytosis-leukostasis syndrome is 5%

questions.text: A 28-years-old woman is brought to the psychiatry out-patient department accompanied by her husband. The patient appears quiet during the interview and looks down most of the time. The husband explains how less interested she would appear in most of the activities they would enjoy earlier. He also mentioned of her recent episodes of irritability towards her children on trivial provocations. She is found to have increased her alcohol intake recently from occasional to once a week. She would be lethargic most of the times and would wake up early than her usual days. The husband recalls her wife brought to a psychiatrist 7 years back for decreased need for sleep and over-religiosity. She would then talk relentlessly, unlike now, when she would appear agitated most of the times. What would be the most appropriate line of management in this case?

choices.text: Enrolling her in a deaddiction programme

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

D) Lithium: It is a mood stabilizer given for the treatment of acute and maintenance phase of bipolar affective disorder. The patient in given scenario is having a major depressive episode, with a history of manic/hypomanic episode in the past. In case for the current episode, she is started on antidepressant alone, she would switch into a manic episode, thus leading to a poor prognosis in the long term. Lithium and Lamotrigine are preferred drugs of choice in bipolar depression.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Reassurance and marital therapy: The patient is having clinical depressive episode impairing her socio-occupational functioning. Moreover, she has a past history of bipolar mania, thus requires pharmacological intervention and mere reassurance will lead to a delay in management. Marital conflict is not mentioned in the clinical case scenario, hence, is not the preferred treatment option.

(B) Enrolling her in a deaddiction program: Increase in substance use is common in both manic and atypical depressive episodes. The treatment of the affective episodes will lead to the control of the use of substances.

(C) Sertraline: It is an antidepressant (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor). It is preferred for major depressive episodes/ unipolar depression. If given in a patient with bipolar affective disorder, it is preferred with a concurrent administration of mood-stabilizers, to prevent and affective switch.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Bipolar affective disorder is characterised by one or more episodes of mania or hypomania, lasting for a duration of 1 week or more. It is treated with the use of mood stabilizer along with antipsychotic during the acute phase, and maintenance treatment with mood stabilizer only.

questions.text: A 45 year old oil factory worker presents with abdominal pain and rectal bleeding for past two days ,also he complains that he is having , excessive fatigue and joint pain physical examination shows abdominal tenderness , cutaneous ulcers..on examination the blood pressure is 165/105 mm hg and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated . Antinuclear antibodies, antibodies to double stranded DNA and anti nuclear cytoplasmic antibodies are absent.Most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Poly Arthritis nodosa is rare disorder resulting from vasculitis or blood vessel inflammation multi organ systems are involved in PAN so it shows wide range of symptoms. Most commonly affects Nerves, intestinal tract, heart, joints kidney, medium sized vessel are affected by PAN. Etiology is unknown but reaserchers strongly supports that the autoimmune responses have a major role in PAN. signs and symptoms : fever, fatigue, decreased appitate and weight, myalgia, arthralgia, hard tender nodules/ulcers, abdominal pain, blood in stool, shortness of breath , chest pain and so on.

Choice A : Wegeners granulomatosis causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. anti nuclear cytoplasmic antibodies are present in Wegeners granulomatosis.

Choice B : Takayasu's arteritis is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the largest blood vessel in the body, usually leads to damage to the aorta.

Choice D : Miller Fisher syndrome is a mild form of Guillain- Barré syndrome. It causes nerve damage, resulting in a loss of coordination, reflexes, and muscle control.

Educational objective Polyarteritis nodosa can be rapidly fatal or develop gradually.Biopsy of an affected organ or arteriography of the blood vessels can confirm the diagnosisPolyarteritis nodosa most often develops during middle age, usually when people are in their 50s, but it can occur at any age. It is rare.Polyarteritis nodosa can be mild at first but can worsen rapidly and be fatal within several months.

questions.text: Calculate the plasma osmolality of a child with plasma Na+ 125 mEq/L, glucose 108 mg/dL, and BUN (blood urea Nitrogen) 140mg/dL?
questions.solution:
The plasma osmolality can be calculated based on the following formula:

Osmolality = 2x [Na+] + [glucose]/18+ [BUN]/2.8

Putting these values in formula:

= 2× 125 + 108/18 + 140/2.8

= 250 + 6 + 50

= 306 m Osm/kg.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female was admitted with a complaint of escalating abdominal pain, increased abdominal circumference, and recurrent diarrhea for 2 months. He has a history of consumption of bush teas for 5 months to reduce weight. Physical examination revealed mild jaundice, distended abdomen, and tenderness on RUQ. Laboratory results showed WBC 6.82 × 109/L, Hb 122 g/L, HbsAg (-), ALT 66 U/L, AST 81 U/L, serum total bilirubin 39.7 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 10.6 μmol/L, and ALB 32.8 g/L. CT scan of the abdomen revealed moderate ascites, hepatomegaly, delayed enhancement of parenchyma, and obscure hepatic veins. Which of the following drugs is effective in improving survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Defibrotide

VENO OCCLUSIVE DISEASE:

  • In western countries, Bone marrow transplantation is the commonest risk factor.
  • Bush teas and cytosine arabinoside are risk factors, but mushroom poisoning is not a risk factor.
  • There is no difference between Veno occlusive disease and Budd-Chiari syndrome except for the site of occlusion.
  • The investigation of choice for diagnosis – Biopsy.
  • Treatment of choice: If hepatic failure is present – Liver transplantation.
  • If there is no hepatic failure – side-to-side portocaval shunt.
  • One drug is effective in improving survival – DEFIBROTIDE.

Option A: Feature

  • It is an antioxidant used for the diagnosis as well as treatment of males in fertility.
  • Common side effects are allergic reactions, asthma, and high blood pressure.

Option B: Tenofovir

  • Tenofovir is commonly used to treat hepatitis B.
  • It is also used in the treatment and prevention of AIDS.

Option D: Ibutilide

  • Ibutilide is a class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug.
  • It is used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

questions.text: A patient, 22-year-old male is brought to the opd with consistently increasing stiffness in the back. The surgeon observes that over the last many visits to him the patients ‘Chin Brow angle’ has increased with every visit. What is the patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by consistently increasing stiffness in the spine due to fusion of the vertebrae. As the vertebrae fuse the patient acquires a posture of flexion and in severe cases the vision is limited to narrow area at the feet.

Learning Objectives: Certain appearances provide the clinician an opportunity to make a spot diagnosis.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labour ward. A 27-year-old female delivered a term baby boy by Normal Spontaneous Vaginal delivery with epiosiotomy performed. All of the following statements are true for episiotomies except:

choices.text: Can be either mid-line or medio -lateral
Involvement of anal sphincter is classified 3rd-4th degree perennial tear.
Mid-line episiotomies bleed less, are easier to repair and heal more quickly

questions.solution:
The birth canal is the path made by the pelvic curve through the planes of inlet mid pelvis and outlet, to be taken by the baby. An episiotomy will not increase the size.

Involvement of the anal spincter is called third degree tear and involvement of rectum is Type IV tear. Type III and IV constitute the Complete Perineal tear.

Midline epi bleeds lesser and heals better but can extend into anal sphincter easily. The lateral episiotomy is more inconvenient to the patient and bleeds more, but is more safer as far as tears are concerned

Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani are incised with an episiotomy.

questions.text:
Microcytic hypochromic anemia is seen in -

Anemia of chronic disease
Thalassemia
Iron deficiency
Fanconi’s anemia
questions.solution:
Fanconi's Anemia does not cause microcytic hypochromic anemia.

The causes of microcytic hypochromic anemia are:

  • S = Sideroblastic Anemia
  • I = Iron deficiency Anemia
  • T = Thalassemia
  • A = Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 56-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of ball-rolling movements and projectile vomiting of undigested food particles. There is no history of allergy or drug abuse. Vital signs are within normal range. Physical examination reveals visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a positive succussion splash test. Endoscopy reveals a gastric mass obstructing the pylorus. A biopsy of the lesion revealed gastric adenocarcinoma. Which of the following anemia is a risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pernicious anemia

  • It is an autoimmune disease due to the CD4+ cell-mediated immune response or antibodies against the stomach's parietal cells.
  • In pernicious anemia, there is progressive destruction of parietal cells, and it results in:
    • Decrease hydrochloric acid secretion, which increases gastric pH.
    • Decrease intrinsic factor secretion impairs vitamin B₁₂ absorption.

Option B: Megaloblastic anemia

  • It is a type of megaloblastic anemia that occurs due to vitamin B₁₂ or folate deficiency.
  • In this anemia, the bone marrow produces stem cells that produce enlarged red blood cells.
    • Fatigue
    • Pallor
    • Shortness of breath.
  • Vitamin B₁₂ deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
    • Pancreatic insufficiency
  • Folate/vitamin B9 deficiency occurs due to the following:
    • Decrease intake of green vegetables, fish, and meat.
    • Cohn’s or ulcerative colitis
    • Hemolytic anemia
    • Increase alcohol intake.

Option C: Aplastic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia in which bone marrow does not produce new blood cells.
  • It is an autoimmune disease in which T-cell-mediated autoimmune destruction of bone marrow occurs.
  • It mostly occurs due to the following:
    • Chemotherapy
    • Toxins (benzene)
    • Certain drugs (like chloramphenicol, carbamazepine, and phenytoin)
    • Autoimmune disorder.
    • Parvovirus (short-lived)
  • It manifests the following:
    • Fatigue
    • Pale skin
    • Shortness of breath
    • Severe bruises
    • Increased risk of infection

Option D: Hemolytic anemia

  • It is a type of anemia that occurs due to the early breakdown of red blood cells.
  • Red blood cells have a 120-day life span; if its breakdown occurs, bone marrow has less time to form new RBCs.
  • There are many types of hemolytic anemia:
    • Sickle cell anemia
    • Thalassemia
    • G6PD deficiency
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Jaundice
    • Tachycardia
    • Dyspnea
    • Fatigue
    • Enlarged spleen or liver

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother due to excessive sleepiness for 1 week. It is associated with constipation for 2 weeks. He was delivered at term via normal vaginal delivery and had no medical check-ups afterwards. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a lethargic infant with periorbital puffiness, a large tongue, and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following tests will help diagnose the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: T4 and TSH assay

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism.

  • Hypothyroidism presents with constipation, pallor, edematous facies, open posterior fontanel, umbilical hernia, hypothermia, large tongue, rough, dry skin, hypotonia, and large abdomen.

  • Initial investigation of hypothyroidism includes TSH and T4 levels.

  • TSH level is increased, and T4 is decreased in primary hypothyroidism.

  • TSH level is reduced along with T4 levels in secondary hypothyroidism.

  • Other investigations include thyroid ultrasound and evaluation of radionuclide uptake.

  • Oral levothyroxine is the treatment for hypothyroidism.

Option A: Karyotyping

  • Karyotyping identifies chromosomal disorders such as trisomies and translocations.

  • Hypothyroidism is not a chromosomal disorder.

Option C: Rectal mucosal biopsy

  • A rectal mucosal biopsy is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease, which presents with constipation in the early neonatal period.

  • Rectal mucosal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

Option D: ACTH level

  • ACTH level is used to identify adrenal diseases such as Cushing’s syndrome and Addison’s disease.

  • It has no role in the diagnosis of hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida is shifted or delivery in second stage of labour. Immediately after the delivery of the baby, the resident pulls the cord and along with the placenta, pulls the fundus of the uterus, out of the cervix. The senior obstetrician is called. What should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin to prevent mortality due to hemorrhagic shock and then attempt repositioning
Urgently take-up patient for Huntingtons surgery

questions.solution:
Uterine inversion usually occurs due to :

  • Fundal implantation of placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Cord traction applied before placental separation
  • Abnormally adhered placentation e.g. placenta accreta.

Manual Reposition under tocolytics such as terbutaline, MgSO4, can be done initially to reposition the uterus.

In most cases, manual reposition works.

If it fails, surgical interventions like haultain surgery and huntington procedure may be done.

questions.text: A 9-years-old girl is brought with long standing finger wiggling, flapping of arms, and shrugging of shoulders. She also has a history of delayed language development. The present symptoms were noticed by her mother while she was a toddler. The movements would worsen while should would be watching television or lying down in bed, but will reduce on distraction. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

(B) Motor stereotypies : Motor stereotypies are involuntary rhythmic, repetitive movements that reduce with distraction.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Dystonia: It is sustained contraction of agonist and antagonist muscles of the body. They are triggered by voluntary body movements, are absent during sleep, may or may not be affected by distraction.

(C) Chorea: Rapid, abrupt, irregular, non-stereotyped, random movements, affecting bilateral parts of the body, like face, trunk, and limbs. They worsen during voluntary movements.

(D) Tourette’s disorder: Tourette’s disorders or motor tic disorder have later age of onset (early adolescence). They are for prolonged duration, have premonitory urge prior to the movements, and are partially voluntary. The subside on distraction.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE Characteristics of various types of movement disorders as described against each of the above options.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 3 days of fever and cough productive of yellowish sputum. He has had no symptoms like hemoptysis, weight loss, night sweats, or anorexia. He has not travelled recently and has not had exposure to anyone with similar symptoms The patient was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks ago after an episode of community-acquired pneumonia involving the left lover lobe. He is a chronic smoker with a 45-pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol occasionally. Temperature is 38.1 C (100 6 F), blood pressure is 112/52 mm Hg, the pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 22/min. Oxygen saturation is 90o/o on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and crackles over the left lower lobe. The chest x-ray is consistent with consolidation of the left lower lung zone. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's fever, productive cough, tachypnea, hypoxia, and left lower lobe crackles are all likely due to left lower lobe pneumonia as demonstrated by the area of consolidation on the chest radiograph. The complicating factor is that the patient had pneumonia in the same location only 3 weeks ago The most appropriate next test in the workup is further chest imaging with a CT scan. Given his extensive smoking history, the most concerning possibility is the presence of an obstructing endobronchial neoplasm leading to non-resolving pneumonia. Such masses can be difficult to detect surrounding the area of consolidation on chest radiographs, but chest CT can help make the diagnosis Chest CT would also show a lung abscess or empyema, which could also be contributing to the failure of this patient's symptoms to resolve. Other possible causes of treatment-resistant pneumonia include bacterial resistance, or other pathogens such as Tb or fungus, immune dysfunction, or non-infectious neoplastic or inflammatory conditions mimicking pneumonia If the chest CT is not helpful, bronchoscopy may be needed. Open lung biopsy would only be considered if both chest CT and bronchoscopy were nondiagnostic (Choice D)

Choice B : Although an immune deficiency can result in non-resolving pneumonia, the patient's advanced age makes congenital causes unlikely Furthermore, this patient has no clear risk factor for HIV. Chest CT would be a much better test at the current situation.

Choice C : Lack of night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis makes tuberculosis less likely Obtaining material for mycobacterial cultures, possibly by bronchoscopy, could be considered if CT supports the possibility of mycobacterial infection.

Choice E : Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease from smoking could be a factor in a delayed resolution of pneumonia in this patient, but the greater concern is the presence of an obstructing malignancy. As such chest, CT scan would be the most appropriate next method for detection.

Educational objective: An obstructing endobronchial malignancy should be suspected in patients with an extensive smoking history who have nonresolution of pneumonia A chest CT can help to diagnose such a malignancy as well as other causes of non-resolving pneumonia such as an abscess or empyema.

questions.text: A 26 year old woman presents with infertility. She has regular cycles of 28 days with no dysmenorrhea. Her LMP was on 8th of May. When should her endometrial biopsy should be planned ?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

4.  29th May

Explanation:

To determine the optimal timing for an endometrial biopsy, it is essential to consider the menstrual cycle's phases and the endometrial changes that occur during the cycle. An endometrial biopsy is typically scheduled during the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, which is when the endometrium is at its thickest and most receptive state.

In a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, the phases typically occur as follows:

  • Follicular phase (pre-ovulatory phase): Days 1 to 14 (from the start of menstruation to ovulation).
  • Ovulation: Usually occurs around Day 14 (may vary depending on the individual's cycle length).
  • Luteal phase (post-ovulatory phase): Days 15 to 28 (from ovulation to the start of the next menstruation).

The secretory phase occurs during the latter half of the menstrual cycle (luteal phase) when the endometrium becomes thick and prepares for possible embryo implantation. It usually starts after ovulation and continues until the onset of the next menstrual period.

Given that the patient's last menstrual period (LMP) was on 8th May, and her cycles are regular, we can estimate the timing of her ovulation and the optimal timing for the endometrial biopsy as follows:

  • Ovulation (estimated): Around 14 days after the start of her cycle (28-day cycle), which is around 22nd May.
  • Secretory phase (estimated): From 22nd May until the next menstrual period.

Considering the secretory phase, the most appropriate time for the endometrial biopsy would be around 29th May (approximately a week after ovulation).

Option 1 (22nd May) would be around the time of ovulation, which is not ideal for the endometrial biopsy, as it should be performed during the secretory phase.

Option 2 (8th-12th May) includes the timeframe of the patient's menstrual period and the pre-ovulatory phase, which is not suitable for an endometrial biopsy.

Option 3 (Anytime during the cycle) is not the best choice because the ideal timing for an endometrial biopsy is during the secretory phase, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following can be seen in association with a condition as seen in the following picture
questions.solution:
•The given picture is of anterior uveitis showing large mutton shaped keratic precipitates

Clinical features

•Activity of uveitis is judged by the number of cells in anterior chamber and not KP as they can be there in old healed uveitis.

•Iridocyclitis would come with retrolental flare

•Iris bombe is seen when iris bows tanteriorly due to back pressure and posterior synechia. Causes rise in IOP due to secondary angle closure and need iridotomy

•The most common complication of Pars planitis is cataract- POSTERIOR SUBCAPSULAR CATARACT.

•HLA- B 27 and Behctets can present with ant Uveitis + Hypopyon.

•Diseases causing granulomatous panuveitis- TB, VKH, Behcets, sarcoidosis.

•MC arithritis involved with uveitis: Ankylosing spondylitis   

Synechia

•Formed due to adhesion of posterior surface of iris with lens

•Ring Synechiae: Forms 360 degree synechia of iris margines with lens and causes iris bombe

•Irregular posterior synechiae: Forms festooned pupil

•Total posterior synechiae: Whole iris is plastered to lens  

Festooned pupil

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bloody diarrhea for the last 7 months. He has been taking different antibiotics without any improvement. He has no history of food allergies. On his examination, he looks pale. His stool microscopy shows numerous pus cells. Blood, stool, and urine culture are negative. His colonoscopy reveals a normal rectum along with edema, erythema, and multiple ulcerative punched-out lesions with necrotic as well as hemorrhagic surfaces being noted throughout the length of the colon in a patchy distribution. His Barium study is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulcerative Colitis

  • The barium study shown above suggests a Lead pipe appearance in the colon. It is the classical barium enema finding in chronic ulcerative colitis.

  • Other findings of Ulcerative colitis are fine mucosal granularity and pseudopolyp.

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease causing inflammation and ulcers in the digestive tract.

  • The clinical features may include:

    • Abdominal pain.

    • Bloody diarrhea.

    • Loss of appetite.

    • Weight loss.

    • Recurrent infections.

  • Ulcerative colitis is diagnosed on barium study and colonoscopy, along with a biopsy.

  • Chron's disease is another type of IBD.

  • Balsalazide, mesalamine, olsalazine, and sulfasalazine are the most effective immunosuppressants to treat ulcerative colitis.

  • Steroids are given to control the flare of ulcerative colitis.

 

Feature  Ulcerative Colitis  Crohn Disease 
Distribution  Continuous  Discontinuous (skip)
Symmetry  Symmetric  Asymmetric 
Fat halo sign location  Colon  Small bowel 
Side  Left-sided or diffuse  Right-sided or diffuse
Rectum  Involved  Often not involved 
ileocecal valve  Open  Stenosed 
Small-bowel involvement  Terminal ileum only  Any small-bowel segment 
Terminal ileum involvement  Backwash ileitis  String sign 
Fat  Perirectal fat increased  Mesenteric fat increased 
Pericolonic stranding  Rare  Frequent 
Lymph nodes  Not enlarged  Usually enlarged 
Fistulae  No  Yes 
Toxic megacolon  Yes  Yes 
Stricture  Yes  Yes 
Abscess  Yes Yes 

Option B: Crohn’s disease

  • Crohn's disease is a kind of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and the other is Ulcerative colitis.

  • investigation of choice in crohns disease is CT enterography.

  • Crohn's disease causes inflammation of the tissues in the digestive tract, mainly involving the terminal ileum and parts of the colon.

Option C: Plummer-Winson syndrome

  • It is a disorder in which there is a triage of iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and dysphagia.

  • Seen in young females.

  • High risk of squamous cell carcinoma pharynx.

Option D: Chiladiti syndrome

  • Chilaiditi syndrome is a condition when pain is felt due to the transposition of a loop of the large intestine (usually transverse colon) in between the diaphragm and the liver, visible on plain abdominal X-ray or chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 33-yr-old male presented to your clinic with numbness from the lower trunk to the distal lower extremities, anteriorly and posteriorly, bilaterally equal. On examination, reflexes were hyperactive, and hypoesthesia was present with the neurological pinwheel exam. Initial investigations were done. A probable diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis was made. Which of the following tests is not useful for evaluating the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Electronystagmogram

  • Electronystomogram is not used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
  • It is used in patients with problems of vertigo and balance problems.
  • It helps in the diagnosis of Meniere's disease

Investigation of multiple sclerosis

  • Evoked Potentials 
  • E.P. marked delay in the latency of a specific E.P. component (as opposed to a reduced amplitude or distorted wave shape) is suggestive of demyelination
  • Cerebrospinal Fluid 
  • CSF abnormalities found in M.S. include a mononuclear cell pleocytosis
  • Increased level of intrathecally synthesized IgG.Oligoclonal bands
  • The total CSF protein is usually normal or mildly elevated.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging 
  • Lesions are frequently oriented perpendicular to the ventricular surface, corresponding to the pathologic pattern of perivenous demyelination (Dawson's fingers).
  • Lesions are multifocal within the brain, brainstem, and spinal cord.

​​​​​​​

  • MRI figure showing periventricular plaques characteristic of multiple sclerosis

Option A: Lumbar puncture

  • Lumbar puncture is done for CSF, which is crucial for diagnosis as it shows oligoclonal bands characteristic of M.S.

Option B: Gadolinium-enhanced MRI

  • MRI is the first line of investigation for M.S., and it shows periventricular plaques

​​​​​​​Option C: Visual evoked potential

  • Visual evoked potential can help in diagnosing M.S. as it can detect the abnormalities in the nerves

questions.text: An 85-year-old ventilator-dependent male was endotracheally intubated 10 days ago. He remains unresponsive and is not a candidate for early extubation. The intensive care unit (ICU) attending elects to perform tracheotomy at the bedside. During the procedure, copious dark blood is encountered. questions.text: A 30-year-old man with end-stage cystic fibrosis undergoes lung transplantation. Three years later, he has a 6-month progressive decline in his renal function. Which of the following medications is the most likely etiology of this?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease is a common finding in patients after lung transplantation and is associated with poorer outcomes. While rarely patients may have hemolytic-uremic syndrome underlying the kidney disease, it is usually acute, and the most common etiology of gradually progressive decline in renal function is calcineurin inhibitor neuropathy. Cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors commonly used in immunosuppressive regimens after lung transplantation. The exact mechanism of this toxicity is unclear but may include direct toxicity of inhibition of the calcineurin-NFAT system within the kidney, alteration in glomerular blood flow, and host/environment interactions within the kidney with calcineurin inhibitors.

Prednisone, albuterol, and mycophenolate mofetil are not known to be nephrotoxic.

INCORRECT OPTION

OPTION A : Prednisiolone administered after lung transplasnsation prevents damage to transplanted lungs by the immune system. Side effects of long-term prednisolone therapy include atrophy of the adrenal gland and osteonecrosis of Hip joint.

OPTION C : Albuterol (Salbutamol) short-acting β? adrenergic receptor agonist is useful in exacerbation of asthma by dilating the airway by acting on smooth muscles.

OPTION D : Mycophenolate mofetil action by selective inhibition of B cell and T-cell proliferation by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the de novo pathway of purine synthesis. Declining renal function is not seen with the use of mycophenolate.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE : Chronic kidney disease is a common finding in patients after lung transplantation and is associated with poorer outcomes. The most common etiology of gradually progressive decline in renal function is calcineurin inhibitor neuropathy. Cyclosporine and tacrolimus.

questions.text: A 35-years-old male came in for consultation. Previously he had a flat mole over his forearm which is of 2-4 cm in diameter. In the last few weeks there is a rapid change in size and shape of the mole. Alarmed by this sudden change, he came in for consultation. At present the lesion is still flat and with irregular borders. What is the most likely diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Melanoma is a cancer of melanocytes and can, therefore arise in skin, mucosa, retina and the leptomeninges. Cutaneous melanoma is caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation. Its rise in incidence reflects increased recreational activity in the sun. Cumulative ultraviolet exposure favors the development of lentigo malignant melanoma and later onset of disease, whereas ‘flash fry’ exposure, typical of rapidly acquired, holiday tans, favors of other morphological variants and early onset of disease. Only 10-20% of malignant melanoma from in pre-existing nevi, with the remainder arising de novo in previously normally pigmented skin. The most likely nevi to form malignant melanoma are atypical nevi, atypical junctional lentiginous nevi (usually facial) and giant pigmented congenital nevi. Macroscopic features in a pre-existing nevus that suggest malignant change are change in size, shape, colour, thickness (elevation/ nodularity or ulceration), satellite lesions (pigment spreading into surrounding area), tingling/itching/ serosanguinous discharge (usually late signs).

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common presentation (70%) usually arising in a pre-existent nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation. Nodularity within superficial spreading melanoma heralds the onset of the vertical growth phase.

Choice B - lentigo maligna melanoma. It was previously also known as Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle. This variant presents as slow growing, variegated brown macule on the face, neck or hands of the elderly. They are positively correlated with prolonged, intense sun exposure, affecting women more than men. They account for between 5% and 10% of malignant melanoma.

Choice C - amelanotic melanoma. It may present as a flesh colored skin lesion; as a metastasis from an unknown skin primary; or in the gastrointestinal tract, with obstruction or intussusception.

Choice D - desmoplastic melanoma. It is mostly found on the head and neck region. It has a propensity for perineural infiltration and often recurs locally if not widely excised. It may be amelanotic clinically.

Learning objective Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common presentation (70%) usually arising in a pre-existent nevus after several years of slow change, followed by rapid growth in the preceding months before presentation.

questions.text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to bluish discolouration of both lower extremities. The patient was born prematurely at 35th-week gestation via normal vaginal delivery to a 23-year-old primigravida, who did not seek prenatal care. On examination, his temperature is 37.2 (98.9F), blood pressure is 89/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 118/min, and respiratory rate is 24/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95% in the right upper extremity but 83% in the left lower extremity. 100% oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous machine-like murmur radiating to the interscapular area. Chest examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following is true regarding the abnormal structure involved in this condition?

choices.text: It undergoes anatomic closure within 24 hours of birth
It connects the superior vena cava with the pulmonary vein
It undergoes physiologic closure within 24 hours of birth
It is a derivative of ligamentum venosum

questions.solution:
Option C: It undergoes physiologic closure within 24 hours of birth

  • This infant's presentation is consistent with patent ductus arteriosus, including bluish discolouration of both lower extremities, the discrepancy between oxygen saturation of upper and lower limbs, and a continuous machinery murmur radiating to the interscapular area.

Ductus arteriosus:

  • It connects the aorta with the pulmonary artery.
  • It undergoes physiological closure immediately after birth or within 24 hours of birth by contraction of the muscular wall. It undergoes anatomic closure 10-21 days after birth by the proliferation of intima. After obliteration, it forms a ligament arteriosum.
  • It allows most of the blood from the right ventricle to bypass the fetus’s fluid-filled non-functioning lungs and directly drain into the left heart.
  • It may remain patent, particularly in preterm infants, maternal rubella infection or hypoxia.
  • Continuous machinery murmur radiating to the interscapular or left infraclavicular region may be heard in the patent ductus arteriosus.

  • The ductus arteriosus is kept open with the help of prostaglandins (PGE1) in ductus-dependent conditions. Prostaglandin inhibitors (NSAIDs) are used to close the ductus arteriosus. NSAIDs, like Intravenous indomethacin or ibuprofen, are used to treat patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants.

Option A: It undergoes anatomic closure within 24 hours of birth

  • Ductus arteriosus undergoes physiologic closure immediately after birth or within 24 hours of birth, not anatomic closure.

Option B: It connects the superior vena cava with the pulmonary vein

  • The ductus arteriosus connects the aorta with the pulmonary artery.
  • It does not connect the superior vena cava with the pulmonary vein.

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus causes holosystolic murmur.

  • Patent ductus arteriosus causes continuous machinery murmur, not holosystolic murmur.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of hypopigmented macules predominantly over extensor surfaces. On examination, he has depigmented lesions with a white forelock as shown below:



An extensive workup reveals a mutation in a c-KIT gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Piebaldism

  • This patient with hypopigmented skin lesions and a white forelock most likely has Piebaldism.
  • Piebaldism (from the words "pie" [magpie, black and white bird] and "bald" [bald eagle]) or piebald trait is a rare, autosomal dominant disorder of melanocyte development and migration, resulting in patchy depigmentation of hair and skin.
  • Affected individuals have lighter patches of skin (leukoderma) and hair (poliosis), most commonly located near the frontal hairline. The localized patch of white hair (white forelock) is the most distinctive feature of Piebaldism.
  • Piebaldism is a nonprogressive, benign disorder and mainly a cosmetic concern that may run in families for generations. Treatment options are limited and include cosmetic camouflage, hair dye, and, for severe cases, autologous skin transplants.

Other features of Piebaldism are:

  • Autosomal dominant genetic disorder of pigmentation
  • Associated with mutations of the c-KIT gene.
  • Common characteristics:
    • Predominantly over extensor aspects.
    • Depigmented lesions with white forelock [part of frontal skin &
    • frontal hair follicles appear white].
    • Scattered normal pigmented and hyperpigmented macules.

Option B Lentigines

  • They occur due to increased localized number of melanocytes. Hyper-pigmented macules are seen(Macules: neither raised nor depressed, <0.5cm lesions, only change in color is present in lesions). This patient has hypopigmented macules and most likely has Piebaldism.

Option C vitiligo

  • It has depigmented/ white Lesions due to the absence of melanocytes. This is an autoimmune condition. Autoimmune conditions are less likely at this stage. This patient most likely has Piebaldism.

Option D Tinea versicolor infection

  • It usually results in hypopigmented lesions on the back. Lesions are itchy. This patient with painless, non-itchy lesions most likely has Piebaldism.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman complains of anal itching and burning. Physical examination reveals an erythematous, scaly lesion, 3 cm in circumference, within the anal canal. The intersphincteric groove can not be appreciated in the area of the lesion. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Appropriate initial management includes which of the following?

choices.text: Metronidazole 250 mg PO QID for 14 days

questions.solution:
Extramammary Paget’s disease may be found in the axilla and in the anogenital region, including the labia majora, penis, scrotum, groin, pubic area, perineum, perianal region, thigh, and buttock. Paget’s disease of the perianal area is a malignant neoplasm of the intraepidermal portion of apocrine glands with or without associated dermal involvement. Paget’s disease has a long preinvasive phase, but if untreated, an invasive adenocarcinoma of the apocrine gland type develops. The disease is more common in women than men, with the highest incidence in the seventh decade.

Macroscopically, the lesion appears as an erythematous scaly or eczematoid plaque-like lesion, similar to other benign perianal lesions, making clinical diagnosis difficult. A definite diagnosis is made by biopsy, which shows characteristic histologic appearance—large, pale, vacuolated cells with hyperchromatic eccentric nuclei. The cells invariably contain acid mucosubstances, an important feature in distinguishing this lesion from melanoma and Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: You are a third-year resident in the surgery department. During a sphincterotomy procedure for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, the chief surgeon passes on the surgical blade to you and tells you to continue the procedure. To minimize the chance of pancreatic duct injury during surgery, you should make the incision at which of the following positions in the ampulla?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11 o’clock position

  • Sphincterotomy is performed from 10 to 11 o’clock position. 
  • Placing the incision at this location in the ampulla minimizes the chance of pancreatic duct injury, which is generally located opposite the planned sphincterotomy site.

Option A: 3 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 3 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option B: 6 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 6 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option C: 9 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 9 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis, comes with tiny papules over his abdomen and chest. The patient is also feeling unusually weak and tired for a couple of weeks. Examination revealed superficial dermal granulomas surrounding hair follicles and sweat ducts. AFB of lesions is negative with elevated serum WBC count. The patient is anemic with hemoglobin of 10 g/dl and MCV of 65 fl. An image of the patient is given below; based on characteristic findings and involvement of sweat glands and hair follicles, these pathologies are seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lichen Scrofulosorum

  • The patient is presented with the diagnosis of Lichen Scrofulosorum.
  • Lichenoid eruption of minute papules occurring in children and adolescents with TB.
  • Skin-colored, closely grouped lichenoid papules occur in perifollicular distribution, mainly found on the abdomen, chest, back, and proximal limbs

  • Pathological examination: Superficial dermal granulomas surrounding hair follicles and sweat ducts and occupy several dermal papillae, foreign body granuloma without caseation.
  • Some patients develop anemia of the chronic disease and present with low Hb.
  • Mycobacterium is not seen and cannot be cultured from biopsy material.
  • Treatment
    • Anti-Tuberculosis Therapy.
    • Lesions clear in 4-8 weeks without scaring.

  • Wedge-shaped necrosis in the dermis, tuberculoid infiltrates & obliterative vasculitis.

questions.text: A final-year medical student is attending a lecture on "Antenatal Radiological Evaluation" by the Gynecology department head. He is asked a question by the professor " By which week does the early diastolic notching of uterine artery disappears" Which of the following is the correct answer to this question?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 22 weeks

  • The early diastolic notch of the uterine artery doppler waveform analysis is assumed to be caused by significant blood flow resistance.

  • It has been linked to intrauterine growth restriction, pregnancy-induced hypertension, and worse perinatal outcomes.

  • Diastolic notching in uterine artery Doppler usually disappears beyond 22 weeks of gestation.

  • Persistence of uterine notch beyond 22 weeks is an indicator of pre-eclampsia.

​​​​​​​

Option A : 20 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

Option B: 21 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

Option D: 32 weeks

  • Diastolic notching of the uterine artery disappears by 22 weeks in normal pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2, LSCS 10 months back presents with history of irregular bleeding. HCG value is 66,700 mIu/mL. Ultrasound reveals a discrete central heterogenous with local invasion into myometrium, with normal ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of irregular bleeding after delivery with raised HCG and invasive mass on ultrasound is suggestive of persistent trophoblastic disease, most likely a choriocarcinoma (follows a nonmolar pregnancy)

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)

  1. Invasive mole: Develops after molar pregnancy only. Very rarely follows other gestations
  2. PSTT (Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor): may follow any type of gestation
  3. Choriocarcinoma: 2/3rd cases after normal delivery, 1/3rd cases after molar pregnancy
  4. Epitheloid Trophoblastic tumor: remote antecedant pregnancy

NOTE: After a nonmolar pregnancy, persistent GTN always has the histologic pattern of choriocarcinoma.

Histologic characterization of choriocarcinoma depends on sheets of anaplastic syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast without chorionic villi.

The choriocarcinoma is classically a soft, fleshy, yellow-white tumour with a marked tendency to form large pale areas of ischemic necrosis, foci of cystic softening, and extensive haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a complaint of hypermenorrhea for 3 months. Her ultrasonography scan reveals a 3.6-cm submucous uterine myoma protruding into the uterine cavity. Subsequently, she underwent a successful 2-hour hysteroscopic myomectomy. However, postoperatively she is experiencing headaches, vomiting, nausea, and lethargy, which is followed by seizures. What can be the most common cause of seizures in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hyponatremia

  • Hyponatremia is the most common electrolyte abnormality in hospitalized patients, and values <120 mEq/dl lead to cerebral oedema and resultant seizures. 
  • Hyponatremia is strongly associated with seizures which are usually generalized tonic-clonic, but partial seizures may also occur.
  • Plasma Na+ concentration less than 135 mEq/L is a very common disorder in up to 22% of hospitalized patients.
  • This disorder is almost always the result of an increase in circulating Arginine vasopressin (AVP) and increased renal sensitivity to AVP, combined with an intake of free water; a notable exception is hyponatremia due to the low solute intake.

Option B: Hypernatremia

  • ECF concentration of Na is 142mEq/l, and ICF concentration is 14 mEq/l, so further rise or Hypernatremia will not affect resting membrane potential, and there are no seizures. 
  • Hypernatremia impairs neurons' plasticity and blocks the transmission of neurotransmitters.

Option C: Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia rarely causes symptoms in the CNS, and seizures do not occur.
  • Hypokalemia increases the resting membrane potential—i.e. hyperpolarization.
  • This results in membrane hyperpolarization and increased excitation.

Option D: Hyperkalemia

  • Hyperkalemia rarely causes symptoms in the CNS, and seizures do not occur.
  • Initially, potassium influx is higher as the cell is more permeable.
  • Potassium influx causes partial depolarization, so excitability Initially increases. 
  • During repolarization, Potassium cannot go outside due to loss in a concentration gradient, so overall excitability decreases, and thus, no seizures occur.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with pathological fractures of the clavicle and ribs. X-ray shows periosteal resorption of second and third metatarsals and phalanges. Urinary and serum calcium levels are raised. The doctor decided to send her for a radionuclide scan of the parathyroid gland. Which of the following finding can be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hot spots:

  • Tc-99m-sestamibi is a radiopharmaceutical that is taken up by cells with a high concentration of mitochondria
  • It is a highly cellular/metabolically active tissue such as the myocardium of the heart.
  • But also abnormal tissues such as oxyphil cell parathyroid adenomas, myeloma, and breast cancer (the basis of so-called scintimammography).
  • Tc99m-sestamibi is absorbed faster by a hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland than by a normal parathyroid gland.
  • This is dependent on several histologic features within the abnormal parathyroid gland itself.
  • The hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland will take up more of the Tc99m-sestamibi and show up 'brighter' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures. These are known as hot spots.
  • The hypo-functioning parathyroid gland will take up less of the Tc99m-sestamibi and show up 'darker' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures. These are known as cold spots.
  • This patient presents with signs of hyperparathyroidism, which suggests a parathyroid adenoma.

Therefore, a parathyroid adenoma will be a hot spot on a parathyroid scan.

parathyroid scan. The scan shows focal area of... | Download Scientific Diagram" src="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/315653235/figure/fig1/AS:614013813673984@1523403709034/Technetium-99m-sestamibi-parathyroid-scan-The-scan-shows-focal-area-of-increased-uptake.png" style="height:202.129px; margin:0px; width:415px" />

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cold spots:

  • The hypo-functioning parathyroid gland takes up less of the Tc99m-sestamibi and will show up 'darker' than the other normal parathyroid glands on the gamma camera pictures.
  • These are known as cold spots.

 

Option C - Panda sign:

  • The 'panda sign' is a 67Ga scan finding caused by bilateral involvement of the parotid and lacrimal glands due to sarcoidosis combined with normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.

 

Option D - Hawkin’s sign:

  • The Hawkins sign can be seen on anteroposterior ankle radiographs 6–8 weeks after a vertical fracture of the neck of the talus.

questions.text: A 69-year-old well-controlled, hypertensive man was seen in ER with 3-month history of mild headache and sudden onset of hemiparesis. On examination, he exhibit mild dysphasia and lethargy. His cognitive function testing indicates moderate diminution of his recent memory and executive function. His hemiparesis is more dense in arm and leg and is mild in his face.CT scan without contrast demonstrates a 3-cm irregular hemorrhage surrounded by marked edema and mass effect in frontal-temporal region. The most likely cause of bleed is?
questions.solution: History of recent onset of headache in adult should always raise the suspicion of neoplasm. Amyloid angiopathy and hypertension are frequent cause of the intracerebral hemorrhage in elderly, but the critical difference with neoplastic bleed is the presence of edema and mass effect which is disproportionate to the size of the hemorrhage. The presence of edema suggests a preexisting lesion with recent bleed. Although intraparenchymal hemorrhage can produce edema but it takes many hours to develop. Therefore, the presence of edema in early hours after the ictus is indicative of underlying pathology. AVMs and coagu-lopathies also can cause intraparenchymal bleed without surrounding edema which is the hallmark of an underlying lesion.

questions.text: When you were in the OPD department, a young mother brought her child to your clinic for consultation. The main complaint is a lesion present on the child’s skin as shown below. This condition is considered to be a potential risk factor for melanoma. There is no familial history of this condition. Which among the following condition is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Giant congenital pigmented nevus (GCPN) is also known as Giant hairy nevus. This nevus causes great deal of confusion as its definition and management is contentious. It is a hamartoma of nevo-melanocytes that has a tendency to dermatomal distribution. It has a similar histology to compound nevi, but the nevus cells are distributed variably from the epidermis throughout all layers and into the subdermal fat and muscle. GCPNs are precursors of melanoma, but the magnitude of risk is unclear, largely due to the lack of well conducted studies and variable classification of the nevus. A 3-5% lifetime risk of melanoma is quoted. 1 in 3 childhood malignant melanomas arise in patients with GCPN, but the risk decreases with age: 15% of malignant melanomas present at birth; 62% present by puberty and 99% by 45 years of age. A multidisciplinary management approach is advocated, with initial investigations examining for neurocutaneous melanosis as there may be leptomeningeal involvement. Removal of GCPN should be considered for both aesthetic and oncological reasons.

Choice B - nevus of Ito. It is characterized by dermal melanocytotic in the shoulder region and can occur simultaneously in patients with nevus of Ota.

Choice C - dysplastic nevus. (atypical nevus). To be atypical nevi, lesions must have three of the following characteristics: variegated pigmentation; ill-defined borders; undulating irregular surfaces; or measure > 5 mm. Histologically they are irregular proliferations of melanocytes at the basal layer of epidermis. They can be sporadic or familial (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome)

Choice D - nevus spilus. These are similar in appearance of café au lait spots, but with hyperpigmented speckles throughout. They are benign lesions that are associated with cutaneous diseases, but whose speckled appearance can be confused with malignant change.

Learning objective GCPN is a hamartoma of nevo-melanocytes that has a tendency to dermatomal distribution. It has a similar histology to compound nevi, but the nevus cells are distributed variably from the epidermis throughout all layers and into the subdermal fat and muscle. GCPNs are precurosrs of melanoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with his wife and presents with acute onset of severe pain in his right great toe. He has long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On physical examination, inflammation and erythema of the affected joint are visible. On x-ray, rat bite erosions with overhanging edges are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Gouty arthritis

  • Patient with arthritis due to gout often presents with swollen, red, and painful asymmetric joints.
  • Risk factors of gout include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, chronic alcohol use, and dyslipidemia.
  • A painful metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the classical manifestation of gouty arthritis.
  • Tophus formation often occurs on the olecranon bursa, Achilles tendon, and external ear.
  • Radiographically, the typical finding of gout is a punched-out lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin and overhanging edge, defined as the "Martel sign" or "rat-bite" erosion.

 

Figure: Gouty arthritis

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • The radiographic hallmarks of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, joint space narrowing and marginal erosions.

Option C: Osteoarthritis

  • The radiographic findings of primary osteoarthritis are-
    • Nonuniform loss of joint spaces
    • Osteophyte formation
    • Cyst formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis.
  • The radiographs of an initial stage of osteoarthritis may not show all of the findings

 

Option D: Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • Radiographic findings of ankylosing spondylitis are bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis (earliest feature), bamboo-spine (knobby spine, poker back or universal syndesmophytes), syndesmophytes, and enthesitis.
