questions.text: Which one of these four images is most likely to be a premalignant condition:
questions.solution:
A – Sub Mucous fibrosis

B – Geographic tongue

C – Candidiasis

D – Fordyce Spots

Sub Mucous fibrosis is a premalignant disorder characterised by inflammation and progressive fibrosis of the sub mucosal tissues inside the mouth.

Sub mucous fibrosis is often associated with chewing betel nuts.

It is due to chronic exposure to arecoline present in the betel nuts.

questions.text: A 64-year-old female presented to the emergency room with an episode of chest pain was diagnosed with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following statement is wrong about hypertrophic cardiomyopathy ?

choices.text: Systolic dysfunction arises due to mitral valve displacement
Adapted mitral valve result in anteriorly directed mitral regurgitation

questions.solution:
Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

  • Interventricular septum typically shows maximum hypertrophy
  • 30% cases show obstruction at rest while other 30% show when put on exercise.
  • Enlarged mitral valve pushesh against spetum and adaptation later may result in posteriorly directed mitral regurgitation
  • Harsh ejection systolic murmur is observed

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have anovulatory cycles. On the use of ovulation-inducing drugs, the follicle grows to a certain size but fails to ovulate. Before ovulation, the development of granules in the follicles is dependent on:-
questions.solution:
Option D : Initial phase of follicular development before entering the menstrual cycle i.e from primordial to Antral follicle is independent of gonadotropins.Early follicular phase is FSH dependent. Late follicular phase is LH & FSH (both) dependent. Development of cortical granules in the follicle, is dependent on LH, hence LH is required for its final maturation, prior to ovulation

Option A : Estrogen is produced from the follicle and is responsible for endometrial proliferation

Option B : Progesterone is produced from the corpus luteum after ovulation

Option C : FSH mainly acts in the initial part of the menstrual cycle, causes stimulation of follicles for growth

questions.text: A primigravida 36 yrs old in her second trimester of pregnancy comes to the clinic for her antenatal visit and was advised to undergo a triple test by her gynecologist. It is used for screening of Down syndrome in 2nd trimester. The test includes all the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Triple test:

  • Used for screening of Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • It includes:
    • AFP (α-fetoprotein)
    • β-HCG (β-human chorionic gonadotropin)
    • Unconjugated estriol
  • Detection rate is 67%

** Quadruple test:

  • Triple test + Inhibin A
  • It is also used as screening test for Down syndrome in 2nd trimester
  • Detection rate is 77%

questions.text: A fifty-year-old man came to your clinic complaining of decreased and blurry vision in his left eye. He also says that he has a white circle in his eye. A diagnosis of cataract is made, and you schedule surgery for its removal. During surgery, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery occurs. The surgery is immediately terminated, and the patient is admitted for further evaluation. Which of the following is not true regarding this complication?

choices.text: Bleeding from short posterior ciliary artery into suprachoroidal space

questions.solution:
• The correct answer is

  • Option D. Self resolving: While some complications of ocular surgery can resolve on their own, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery leading to bleeding and associated complications would typically require prompt medical intervention to manage the consequences, such as controlling intraocular pressure and addressing potential complications like suprachoroidal hemorrhage.

  • Here's an explanation of the options:

    Option A. Shallowing of anterior chamber: This can occur due to leakage of intraocular contents, leading to a shallow anterior chamber.

    Option B. Expulsion of intraocular contents: Rupture of the posterior ciliary artery can lead to increased intraocular pressure and expulsion of intraocular contents.

    Option C. Bleeding from short posterior ciliary artery into suprachoroidal space: This is the likely mechanism in this scenario. The short posterior ciliary arteries supply blood to the choroid, and rupture can cause bleeding into the suprachoroidal space, leading to various complications, including shallow anterior chamber and expulsion of intraocular contents.

    d. Self-resolving: While some complications of ocular surgery can resolve on their own, a rupture of the posterior ciliary artery leading to bleeding and associated complications would typically require prompt medical intervention to manage the consequences, such as controlling intraocular pressure and addressing potential complications like suprachoroidal hemorrhage.

questions.text: )A 27-year-old female was advised to get CT scan done. A radiographic image revealed a benign tumor as shown below. Identify the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The organ shown above where benign tumor is located, is liver

  • And the appearance of lesion is called as – central stellate scar

Central stellate scar is seen in

  1. Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)2)
  2. Fibrolamellar variant of Hepatocellular carcinoma
  3. Serous cystadenoma pancreas
  4. Renal oncocytoma

Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH )

  • Second most common benign tumour of liver
  • Young women
  • May be due to hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery
  • Characterised by central fibrous scar with radiating septa although no central scar is seen in approximately 15% of cases
  • Histology - Cords of benign appearing hepatocytes divided by multiple fibrous septa originating from a central scar
  • The central scar often contains a large artery that branches out into multiple smaller arteries in a spoke wheel pattern
  • Contains both hepatocytes and Kupffer cells
  • Associated with OCP use
  • Serum AFP levels are normal
  • Hepatic architecture is maintained
  • IOC– CECT (strong hypervascularity in the arterial phase with central nonenhancing scar)
  • Asymtomatic patients with typical radiologic features do not require treatment
  • Treatment for patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass or in case of diagnostic uncertainty - Resection

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of dyspnoea, chest retrosternal pain and epigastric pain. Chest x-ray showed a large left pleural effusion . A CT scan was performed and revealed pneumomediastinum, left collapsed lung and loculated pleural effusion. A probable diagnosis of Boerrhave syndrome was made. The said diagnosis is due to:
questions.solution:
BOERHAAVE’S SYNDROME

  • Spontaneous rupture usually occurs on the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus into the left pleural cavity or just above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • These patients are typically male (85%), 40 to 60 years of age, who have a history of recent emesis.

Clinical features

  • Mackler’s triad of thoracic pain, vomiting, and cervical subcutaneous emphysema is seen in spontaneous esophageal perforation.
  • Thoracic perforations cause substernal and epigastric pain.
  • Mediastinal emphysema and pleural effusions are common, but early cervical subcutaneous emphysema is noted in only 20% or less of patients.
  • Fever and sepsis develop with increasing contamination and inflammation of the mediastinum and pleural cavities.
  • Patients with an abdominal perforation have epigastric abdominal pain that is also often referred to the back and left shoulder.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with repeated transient loss of consciousness lasting less than 10 minutes. After regaining consciousness, he experienced no disorientation, confusion, or tongue‐biting. He has been diagnosed with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy 3 years ago and is currently on maintenance with Sodium Valproate. Subsequently, an electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a 4-6 Hz polyspike pattern. Which of the following would be this patient's most common additional presentation?

choices.text: Generalized tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

questions.solution:
Option C: Myoclonus

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JANZ syndrome)

  • It is a common form of generalised epilepsy that occurs in otherwise healthy adolescents and presents with the triad of myoclonic jerks, generalised tonic‐clonic seizures, and absence seizures.
  • It is commonly characterised by bilateral myoclonic jerks that may be single or repetitive.
  • It has a Polygenetic inheritance and is strongly associated with a family history
  • Onset is usually 10 -19 years of age.
  • Clinical Features include: Sodium Valproate (lifelong)
    • Myoclonic Jerk (early morning) Prominent in the morning after awakening.
    • Consciousness is preserved unless severe.
    • EEG shows a 4-6 Hz Polyspike pattern.
    • May develop generalised tonic-clonic seizures; in the future, and 30% will also develop absence seizures in the future.
  • Provoking factors include:
    • Sleep deprivation
    • Alcohol withdrawal
  • Treatment:
    • Sodium Valproate (lifelong)

Option A: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures during sleep

  • It is a form of Primary generalised epilepsies that can be seen when a person is asleep.
  • These Seizures may be provoked by:
  • Sleep deprivation 
  • Fatigue, alcohol
  • Fever
  • Menstrual cycle
  • Flashing lights

Option B: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

  • It is the most common form of Primary generalised epilepsies.
  • Onset is 10–25 years of age.
  • EEG shows spikes and waves on waking and sleep onset.
  • It is provoked by Sleep deprivation.
  • Treatment includes sodium valproate.

Option D: Absence seizures

  • Absence seizures (petit mal) always start in childhood > 10 years.
  • They frequently occur (20–30 times a day) and are not associated with post-ictal confusion.
  • Seizures start and finish abruptly (unaware of absence)

questions.text: A 56-year-old lady presenting to OPD with postmenopausal bleeding for 3 months has a 1 x1cm nodule on the anterior lip of cervix. The most appropriate investigation to be done subsequently is
questions.solution:
Post menopausal bleeding with a visible cervical growth needs a tissue diagnosis, done by a punch biopsy of the lesion.

Paps smearis a screening test, done in asymptomatic patients.

Colposcopy + biopsyis a diagnostic test, indicated in symptomatic patients, like those with postmenopausal or post coital bleeding, or in asymptomatic patients where paps screening was done and turned out abnormal

Endocervical curettageis indicated in patients with suspected endocervical lesion, or if entire transformation zone could not be evaluated at colposcopy

questions.text: A young male wanting to join the army is found to have mild jaundice during his medical fitness examinations. He comes to your clinic for further evaluation. The patient has no complaints except for passing dark-coloured urine even though he drinks plenty of water. Further testing revealed a mild increase in his serum total bilirubin levels, with an increase in both conjugated and unconjugated bilirubin levels. His gallbladder can be visualized on oral cholecystography. A liver biopsy is taken, which shows no pigmentation. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rotor Syndrome

  • Rotor syndrome is a mixed hyperbilirubinemia characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice caused by chronic elevation of mostly conjugated (direct) bilirubin due to impaired hepatic storage.
  • It is usually asymptomatic, but patients may present with non-pruritic jaundice.
  • It is a benign disorder and does not require any treatment.
  • Rotor syndrome and Dubin Johnson Syndrome have plenty of similarities, and the difference are listed below:
  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson’s syndrome
Appearance of liver Normal appearance The liver has black pigmentation
Gall bladder visualization on oral cholecystography The gallbladder is usually visualized Gall bladder can't be visualized
Total urine coproporphyrin content High with <70% coproporphyrin I Normal with >80% coproporphyrin I

Option B: Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome

  • Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome and rotors syndrome share a lot of similarities.
  • Both are mixed hyperbilirubinemias.
  • The gallbladder is not visualized in Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome.
  • The liver also shows pigmentation in Dubin Johnson’s Syndrome.

Option C: Crigler-Najjar Syndrome

  • Crigler-Najjar Syndrome is characterized by an increase in unconjugated bilirubin levels only.

Option D: Gilbert Syndrome

  • Gilbert Syndrome is characterized by an increase in unconjugated bilirubin levels only.

questions.text: Not true regarding this type of investigation

choices.text: Easy to do, doesn’t require skilled technician
Can be done in patients with poor vision

questions.solution:
Goldman Perimetry

a.Done in patients of glaucoma

b.Type of manual perimetry

c.Uses both static and kinetic technique

d.Can be done in patients with poor vision

e. it requires skilled perimetrists who manually map the visual field without the aid of a computer algorithm.

questions.text: A 64-year-old female is brought with pain in neck and pain radiating down the arm. He has sensory loss over thumb and index finger with weakness of biceps and brachioradialis. What disc id affected?
questions.solution:
C6 Nerve Root compression

Sensory Deficit

Lateral forearm, thumb, and index finger

Motor Weakness

Biceps

Extensor Carpi raidalis longus and brevis

Reflex Change

Biceps

Brachioradialis

Indicative of C5 - C 6 herniation or other local pathological condition at that level.

C6 nerve weakness is indicative of C5/6 herniation as at this level C5 nerve root would have exited between C5 and C6 vertebrae. The C6 will exit between C6 and C7 vertebrae so it’s still within the spinal canal as the traversing nerve and hence amenable to damage.

Learning objective: Knowledge of dermatomes, myotomes and reflex arcs is an essential step in proper neurological assessment of any patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as the initial therapy of documented deep venous thrombosis in a post-operative case?
questions.solution:
Antithrombotic therapy in DVT

  • Any venous thrombosis involving the femoropopliteal system is treated with full anticoagulation ·
  • Traditionally, the treatment of DVT centers around heparin treatment to maintain the PTT at 60 to 80 seconds, followed by warfarin therapy to obtain an INR of 2.5 to 3.0.
  • This initial therapy usually is continued for at least 5 days, while oral vitamin K antagonists are being simultaneously administered.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented with complaints of visual disturbance of the left eye. Clinical findings revealed pterygium. Which of the following is true about pterygium?

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Pterygium

  • Wing shapes fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from the either side
  • Etiology – hot climates
  • Degenerative & hyperplastic condition of conjunctiva

Symptoms

  • Visual disturbance (astigmatism)
  • Cosmetic intolerance Sign
  • Triangular fold of conjunctiva mainly on nasal side
  • Stocker line – iron deposition on corneal epithelium

Rx

  • Surgical excision-recurrence chance is 30-50 %
  • Best RX- Surgical excision with free conjunctival autograft taken from the same eye or other

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid female delivered a term baby boy following assisted vaginal delivery. Which of the following is the most common obstetrics nerve palsy in newborn?
questions.solution:
Brachial plexus and facial nerve injury are the more common types of birth injuries to newborn

Difficult delivery may lead to various obstetric palsies, most common being brachial plexus injury. Erb's paralysis (upper brachial plexus injury) and klumpke's paralysis (lower brachial plexus ) injuries are often described secondary to excessive shoulder traction during difficult labour.

Brachial plexus injury is 1-3 per 1000 deliveries

Facial is 0.2-7.5 of 1000 deliveries (mostly in uncomplicated deliveries and low forceps)

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with High fever, sever unrelenting headache, sensitive to bright light and vomiting. On history taking revels that he had a tour with his classmates to Sahel region of West Africa he returned 3 days before. On the physical examination bradycardia, disorientation, papilledema, altered sensorium, neck stiffness, positive brudzinski's and kernig's sign are present. Physician is strongly doubt for pyogenic meningitis, which criteria is true about CSF finding in pyogenic meningitis.?
questions.solution:
Choice A is correct.

Pyogenic meningitis is inflammation of meninges then affects pia matter, arachnoid, sub arachnoid space and spinal cord. pyogenic meningitis is a acute onset disease with serious infection and associates marked inflammatory exudation, usually caused by bacterial infection. pyogenic meningitis maybe fatal if untreatend. Early symptoms of meningitis include: nausea and vomiting, fever ,headache and a stiff neck, muscle pain, sensitivity to light, confusion, cold hands or feet and mottled skin ,in some cases, a rash that does not fade under pressure csf finding shows increased protein and decreased sugar. Protein leaks into the subarachnoid space from the blood, resulting in markedly increased CSF protein.

Educational objective: Meningitis due to S. pneumoniae occurs most commonly in the very young and the very old Several strains of bacteria can cause acute bacterial meningitis, most commonly: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus). This bacterium is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in infants, young children and adults

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant brought by his mother to the emergency department is the rush. Upon asking, the mother described that the child was playing while working on her laptop. When she returned to see the child, he was not breathing properly. Examination shows a cyanotic child with no cry but a palpable central pulse. What should be done immediately in such cases?
questions.solution:
Option C: Back thrust and chest compression

  • Foreign bodies in the airways of children have the potential to be lethal. Thus prompt identification is crucial. 

  • Although foreign body aspiration can happen at any age, the greatest incidence is between 6 months and 3 years.

  • The most frequently aspirated materials include coins and small bits of toys, as well as vegetable matter (hot dogs, peanuts, and other edibles).

  • Most children (70%) have been seen to suffer a choking incident during aspiration. Children may further exhibit coughing, dyspnea, or agitation.

  • Manual thrusts to the upper abdomen (Heimlich manoeuvre [abdominal thrust]) or lower chest (chest thrust) are intended to provide a quick increase in intrathoracic pressure, serving as an artificial cough that can aid in the dislodging of a foreign body in the event of choking. The obstacle should be removed with each thrust. If back blows fail to dislodge the object and the infant is still conscious, deliver up to five chest thrusts.

  • For newborns and infants, chest and back thrusts are advised because abdominal thrusts are more likely to result in organ damage (e.g., to the liver or spleen).

Option A: Start CPR

  • Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) is an emergency lifesaving procedure in which a patient has no pulse.

  • In case of severe complete obstruction of the airway tract, if the infant is unconscious and carotid is not palpable, CPR should be initiated immediately.

  • If the infant is conscious or the pulse is palpable, chest and back thrusts should be performed in cases of aspiration.

Option B: Heimlich manoeuver

  • Heimlich manoeuver is recommended in case of foreign body aspiration and complete airway blockage in adults.

  • When an abdominal or chest push is utilised, there is always a chance of internal damage. Hence it is avoided in infants.

Option D: Chest X-ray

  • An aspirated foreign body diagnosis is made using the child’s presenting symptoms, the child’s past medical history, and chest X-rays.

  • Certain non-food things can be observed in the lungs or airways on a conventional X-ray, but most food, vegetable matter, and plastic toys will not show up. However, if there is a window of time and suspicion of foreign body aspiration, the next step would be an X-ray.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the ED by ambulance immediately after a road traffic accident. The patient in ICU receives an emergency blood transfusion as part of the resuscitation efforts. SpO2 is reduced to 75% at room air three hours later with sudden respiratory difficulty. CVP is 15cm water and PCWP is 16 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely associated with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Characterized by acute respiratory distress within 12 hrs of transfusion
Results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies
Leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that decrease capillary permeability
The implicated donors are frequently nulliparous women

questions.solution:
Option B: Results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies

  • The typical presentation of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) is the sudden development of shortness of breath, severe hypoxemia (O2 saturation <90% in room air), and hypotension within 6hr of transfusion.
  • PCWP in TRALI is ≤ 18 mm Hg.
  • TRALI results from the donor plasma that contains high-titre anti-HLA antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability.
  • The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women, and transfusion of their plasma component should be avoided.
  • It can also present with fever (which develops within 6 hours after transfusion) and typically resolves within 48 to 96 hours. 

Option A: Characterized by acute respiratory distress within 12 hrs of transfusion

  • TRALI developed within 6 hours of transfusion and characterized acute respiratory distress.

Option C: Leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that decrease capillary permeability

  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that don't decrease, in fact, increase capillary permeability.

Option D: The implicated donors are frequently nulliparous women

  • Multiparous women have frequently implicated donors of blood transfusions, resulting in transfusion-related acute lung injury.

questions.text: A 19-year-old G4P3 at 23 weeks’ gestation presents with a rapid plasma reagin test (RPR) result of 1:8 .Confirmatory testing is positive. The patient has no signs or symptoms of syphilis. Two years ago, the patient’s RPRwas nonreactive. The treatment plan for this patient should be which of the following?

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, weekly for three doses
Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM, weekly for two doses
Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units IM once
Aqueous procaine penicillin, 4 million units IV every 4 hours for 1 0 days

questions.solution:
Recommended Treatment for Pregnant Women with Syphilis 

Category  Treatment
Early syphilisa  Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly as a single injection - some recommended a second dose 1 week later
More than 1 - year durationb Benzathine penicillin G, 2.4 million units intramuscularly weekly for three doses
Neurosyphilisc

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G, 3-4 million units intravenously every 4 hours for 10-14 days

             or 

Aqueous procaine penicillin, 2-4 million units intramuscularly daily, plus probenecid 500 mg orally four times daily, both for 10-14 days

aPrimary, secondary, and latent syphilis of less than 1-year duration.

bLatent syphilis of unknown or more than 1-year duration, tertiary syphilis.

cSome recommend benzathine penicillin, 2.4 million units intramuscularly after completion of the neurosyphilis treatment regimens.

From the centers for disease control and prevention (2006b).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman was admitted to your hospital with recurrent upper abdominal pain for one year. The patient also had presented with diabetes/glucose intolerance, steatorrhea, gallstones, and achlorhydria.. Computed tomography (CT) indicated an isodense mass of 8.4 cm×3.7 cm in the body and tail of the pancreas with notable enhancement. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Somatostatinoma

  • Gallstones are associated with somatostatinoma.
  • Somatostatinoma:
    • Somatostatinoma syndrome is a triad of diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones, but it also includes weight loss and hypochlorhydria.
    • Because somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions, patients with a somatostatinoma present with gallstones due to bile stasis, diabetes due to inhibition of insulin secretion, and steatorrhea due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion
    • Most somatostatinomas originate in the proximal pancreas or the pancreatoduodenal groove, with the ampulla and periampullary area as the most common site (60%)
    • The most common presentations are abdominal pain, jaundice, and cholelithiasis. Of tumours, 90% are malignant, with metastasis to the liver or lymph nodes commonly noted at the time of diagnosis. They are rarely associated with MEN1 but are associated with Von Recklinghausen disease and pheochromocytoma.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum somatostatin levels, usually >10 ng/mL.
    • Treatment involves complete excision of the tumour and cholecystectomy if there is no metastatic disease

Option A: Insulinoma

  • Insulinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasms and present with a typical clinical syndrome known as Whipple’s triad.
  • The majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and 10% are malignant. They are typically cured by simple enucleation.
  • Approximately 90% of insulinomas are sporadic, and 10% are associated with MEN1 syndrome.

Option B: VIPoma

  • Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide Secreting Tumour (VIPoma) syndrome, also called WDHA (Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) syndrome. This syndrome was described by Verner and Morrison. They are most commonly located in the distal pancreas.

Option D: Glucagonoma

  • Diabetes in association with dermatitis should raise the suspicion of a glucagonoma. The classic necrolytic migratory erythema (due to low levels of amino acids) manifests as cyclic migrations of lesions with spreading margins and healing centres typically on the lower abdomen, perineum, perioral area and feet. Patients also complain of an enlarged sensitive tongue.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels which are usually >500pg/mL. They are more often in the body and tail of the pancreas.

questions.text: A woman presents for the first antenatal visit at 30 weeks. Her sugars , 1 and 2 hours after a 75 gm glucose load are 190 and 188 mg/dL. Which amongst the following statements is true regarding management in this patient?

choices.text: Glyburide is absolutely contraindicated for management
She should be delivered between 34 and 36 weeks of gestation, as there is a risk of sudden IUFD at full term.
Presence of phosphatidyl glycerol in amniotic fluid is 100% confirmatory of lung maturity

questions.solution:
Normal values of OGTT are 92/180/153 (fasting/ 1 hour after 75gm glucose/ 2 hour after glucose load). This is thus a case of GDM with two vales deranged.

  • Unlike other oral hypoglycemic agents, glyburide and metformin both are being increasingly used for GDM (not for overt DM) and are found to be safe.
  • Patients with GDM/DM should be delivered between 38 and 39 weeks of gestation, as there is a risk of sudden IUFD at full term.
  • Hormones which do not cross the placenta are 1. Insulin, 2. PTH, and 3. Calcitonin.
  • Lung maturity is delayed in DM/GDM. L/S >2:1 is not the most reliable indicator. Phosphatidyl glycerol in amniotic fluid is 100% confirmatory of lung maturity in these cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with complaints of right hypochondriac pain and fever. Physical examination revealed that the liver was palpable 5 cm below the right costal margin.He had no history of liver disease. After a thorogh evaluation & imaging, a provisional diagnosis of hepatoblastoma was made. All are true about the said diagnosis except:-

choices.text: Common in cirrhosis of liver due to HBV
Surgical resection is treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Two primary tumors of the liver are

HCC and hepatoblastoma

Hepatoblastoma is common in the pediatric age group and is associated with hereditary conditions like FAP,GARDNER SYNDROME, Beckwith WEIDMAN SYNDROME most common age group for hepatoblastoma is below 3 years of age

HCC

Age group 15-19 years

A/w acquired hepatitis b and c infection and congenital diseases like tyrosinemia, glycogen storage disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was diagnosed to have chronic hepatitis C. He responded to treatment with interferon. However, after one year of follow-up, he showed a relapse of the disease. Which of the following would be the next most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
• Retreatment is indicated for Relapser after a previous course of standard interferon monotherapy or combination standard interferon/ribavirin therapy.
  • A course of PEG IFN plus ribavirin (retreatment not recommended with PEG IFN/ribavirin if relapse occurred after a full course of PEG IFN/ribavirin).
  • Retreatment is also recommended for Non responders to a previous course of standard IFN mono-therapy or combination standard IFN/ribavirin therapy.
  • A course of PEG IFN plus ribavirin—more likely to achieve a sustained virologic response in white patients without previous ribavirin therapy, with low baseline HCV RNA levels, with a2-logl0 reduction in HCV RNA during previous therapy, with genotypes 2 and 3, and without reduction in ribavirin dose.(Retreatment not recommended with PEG IFN/ribavirin if non response occurred to a full course of PEG IFN/ribavirin).

questions.text:
A previously healthy 22-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital after developing a rash over her lower limbs that started 1 week ago and slowly spread up to her knees. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fine petechiae and purpura around her lower legs. There is no lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:
Haemoglobin → 15 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume→ 90 fl.
Platelets→ 12,000/ μL
Leukocytes→ 9,000/ μL
Creatinine, Prothrombin time, Activated partial thromboplastin time, Plasma fibrinogen, Lactate dehydrogenase and D- dimer were normal. Peripheral blood smear shows thrombocytopenia.
The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Corticosteroids

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) is characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia often occurring in the absence of identifiable and specific precipitants. Corticosteroids are a first-line treatment option for patients with symptoms and/or a platelet count of <30,000/μL. Intravenous immunoglobulin can be considered in patients who have failed or have contraindications to steroid therapy or require a more rapid increase in platelet counts.

INCORRECT ANSWERS

A. Plasma exchange is the treatment of choice for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura-hemolytic uremic syndrome in adults.

C. Splenectomy is generally reserved for refractory cases.

D. Circulating platelets are rapidly removed by the autoantibodies, limiting the role of platelet transfusions.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE : Patients with immune thrombocytopenia and platelets >30,000/μLwithout bleeding can generally be observed without treatment. Corticosteroid therapy is a first-line treatment option for immune thrombocytopenic purpura in adult patients with platelets <30,000/μL or with bleeding.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the physician with complaints of dysphagia with episodic melena, muscle pain, rash, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips for 1 week. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and the examination of the hands reveals sclerodactyly, digital pits & ulceration. Initial investigations were done. Which of the following test can be for the diagnosis of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anti-nuclear antibody

  • This is a case of scleroderma in which the patient presents with complaints of dysphagia with frequent regurgitation, chronic Malena, myalgias, pruritus, progressive fatigue and dyspnea on exertion, and painful swelling of his fingers with occasional discoloration in his fingertips.
  • Examination findings of hands in involve sclerodactyly, digital pits &ulceration.
  • Anti-nuclear antibody- ANA is the screening method of choice for systemic rheumatic diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (S.L.E.), mixed connective tissue disease, Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma, CREST syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, polymyositis, and dermatomyositis.
  • These are a group of autoantibodies directed against different nuclear antigens such as D.N.A., R.N.A., histones, etc.
  • ANA can also be found in healthy sometimes.

Option B: U l- Ribonucleoprotein antibody

  • Anti-U1ribonucleo protein antibody is usually known to be a marker of Mixed connective tissue disease.
  • M.C.T.D. is an autoimmune disease with mixed symptoms of polymyositis, S.L.E., and scleroderma.

Option C: Anti- L.K.M antibody

  • The anti-liver-kidney microsomal antibody is found in chronic delta hepatitis.
  • It is sometimes also associated with chronic hepatitis due to the hepatitis C virus.

Option D: Anti- topoisomerase antibody

  • A.T.A. are autoantibodies that are directed against topoisomerase.
  • Mostly associated with scleroderma.
  • A.T.A. is usually not used for screening purposes in scleroderma

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is admitted to the pediatrics ward for the management of diabetic ketoacidosis. She has had a history of diabetes mellitus type I for 5 years and has been non-compliant with the treatment for the last few days. During the workup, the calcium was found to be elevated. In what form will the calcium concentration be maximum in her plasma after she recovers?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ionized form

  • The majority of body reserves of calcium are present in the bones. Only about 1% to 2% of body calcium exists in the extracellular fluid for physiological functions like blood coagulation, exocytosis and endocytosis, muscular contraction, and neuromuscular transmission.
  • The calcium present in the blood plasma is in three forms:
    • Protein-bound
    • Anion-bound
    • Ionized calcium
  • About 50% of the total plasma calcium is in the ionized form. Ionized calcium is that fraction of the calcium in the plasma that is not bound to any proteins and anions and is physiologically active. This represents the most abundant form of calcium in the serum.
  • About 45% of the total plasma calcium is bound to proteins like albumin. Acid-base derangements in the blood can alter calcium binding to the plasma proteins. For example, the H+ ions bind to albumin in metabolic acidosis, and calcium is released from the albumin-binding sites. This can cause transient hypercalcemia.
  • A small portion of the total plasma calcium (about 5%) is complexed with the anions like phosphate and citrate.

Option A: Complexed to phosphate

  • The calcium bound to anions like phosphate represents only a small amount of calcium in the blood plasma.
  • Most of the plasma calcium is in the ionized form.

Option B: Complexed to citrate

  • Citrate is an anion, and the calcium complexed with citrate represents only a minor portion.

Option C: Bound to plasma albumin

  • About 45% of the total plasma calcium is bound to proteins (mainly albumin). This is slightly less than the free ionized form of calcium in the plasma, which represents about 50% of the total serum calcium.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy comes to you at 4 months with concern regarding continuing sodium valproate treatment. Your advice is:

choices.text: Taper sodium valproate and add lamotrigine
Continue sodium valproate with regular monitoring of serum levels

questions.solution:
As the patient has already finished the first trimester (teratogenic period), it is best to continue with the same AED.

However, during pregnancy, because of hemodilution, the dose of AED needs to be generally increased and hence therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) should be done for all AEDs.

questions.text: A newborn baby has an APGAR score of 9 at birth, but developed excessive frothing and choking on attempted feeds. The investigation of choice is :

choices.text: X-ray chest with the red rubber catheter passed per orally into esophagus.

questions.solution:
The above findings suggest a clinical diagnosis of tracheoesophageal fistula, which usually occurs in association with esophageal atresia but may also occur as an isolated anomaly.

Plain radiography may show air in esophagus and stomach (most common variety being upper end of esophagus, being blind, and lower end connected to trachea).  A X-ray chest with red rubber (radio opaque) catheter passed orogastrically is diagnostic and catheter is seen curling in the pouch,. Using air as contrast, the outline of the pouch is visible on x-ray.  

Contrast study of esophagus (with water soluble low-osmolarity nonionic contrast agent) is some times needed for the confirmation the diagnosis. If simple swallow doesn't show the fistula, modification may be required in the form of contrast injection into NG tube with patient prone and as the tube (Rubber) is withdrawn the fistula is seen and this technique is useful for detecting H type of fistula.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male underwent a laparoscopic right-sided hemicolectomy because of colon carcinoma, under general (propofol-based) anaesthesia in combination with epidural anaesthesia. The surgery was successful, and patient recovery was excellent according to the Early Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocol. On arrival at the ward, the patient was hesitant to discuss penile complaints with attending female nurses. After 1 day of persistent painful erections, the patient notified the treating physician. On close inspection, painful engorgement of the penis in absence of sexual arousal was observed. All of the following statements are correct about this condition except?

choices.text: High flow priapism occurs secondary to penile or perineal trauma
Low flow priapism can lead to compartment syndrome
Winter’s procedure is percutaneous cavernoglandular shunt for priapism

questions.solution:
Answer is 3 as mainly diagnosis is done clinically .

PRIAPISM

  • Persistent painful erection in absence of sexual excitement / desire or it persist after sexual excitement / desire
    • Min duration of painful erection – 24 hours
    • It is an emergency & delay in treatment leads to Cavernosal fibrosis & impotence
    • It should be treated within 6 hours to prevent other complications
    • Priapism is of 2 types
High Flow Low Flow (MC)
  • Non- Ischemic

Causes

  • Penile Trauma
  • Perineal trauma
  • Due to formation of arterial sinusoidal shunts.
  • Ischemic

Causes

  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Leukemia
  • Fat emboli
  • Spinal cord lesion
  • Malignant Penile inflammation
  • Trazadone Injection

Clinical Presentation

  • In children (5 – 10 years) with sickle cell disease - Painful erection during nights
  • In Adults – iatrogenic

Diagnosis

  • Mainly clinical
  • Doppler is helpful in diagnosis

Treatment

  • If patient comes within 4-6 hrs.- ketamine injection given (> 50% cases improve)

↓ No improvement

Aspiration & saline irrigation

↓ No improvement

Hyaluronidase injection

  • For High flow priapism – Selective internal Pudendal Angiography f/b embolization of feeding vessel.

Another surgical option - Shunts [Blood is shunted from corpora cavernosa]

  • Corporo-glanular shunt – Winter shunt
  • Corporo-spongiosal Shunt – QUACKEL or SACHER shunt
  • Corporo–saphenous shunt – GRAYHACK shunt
  • Corporo-dorsal vein shunt – BARRY shunt

questions.text: A patient who was using CuT for contraception, presented with a 20 weeks pregnancy. The IUCD is placed at the fundus, tail visible at OS and she wants to continue the pregnancy. What is your next step with this patient:
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

  1. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy

Explanation of each option:

  1. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy: In cases where a patient is found to have a pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place, and the pregnancy is desired to be continued, the best course of action is usually to leave the IUD in place and monitor the pregnancy. If the IUD is not causing any complications and the pregnancy is progressing normally, it can be safely left in-situ. However, close monitoring of the pregnancy and the IUD's position is essential throughout the pregnancy to ensure there are no issues or risks.

  2. Do medical termination of Pregnancy (MTP): Medical termination of pregnancy involves using medications to induce abortion and end the pregnancy. This option is not appropriate in this scenario since the patient wants to continue the pregnancy.

  3. Remove IUCD and continue pregnancy: In some cases, if the IUD is causing complications or is improperly positioned, it may be necessary to remove it. However, if the patient wants to continue the pregnancy and the IUD is not causing any problems, removing it is not mandatory. In many cases, it is safer to leave the IUD in place during the pregnancy, especially if it is embedded in the uterine wall.

  4. Remove IUCD and do MTP: This option involves both removing the IUCD and proceeding with a medical termination of pregnancy. However, since the patient wants to continue the pregnancy, this option is not appropriate.

questions.text: Which amongst the following statements is false about ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Medical therapy fails in at least 5–10% of cases
Alcoholism is a contraindication for methotrexate
Active intra-abdominal haemorrhage is a relative contraindication to medical management
Until the ectopic pregnancy is resolved, folic acid supplements—including prenatal vitamins—should not be taken

questions.solution:
Active intra-abdominal hemorrhage is an absolute contraindication to medical management. The size of the ectopic mass is also important. It is recommended that methotrexate should be avoided if the pregnancy is more than 4 cm, and fetal cardiac activity is present.  

According to ACOG contraindications for methotrexate include: breast feeding, alcoholism, immunodeficiency, liver or renal disease, blood dyscrasias, active pulmonary disease and peptic ulcer. Candidates for methotrexate therapy must be hemodynamically stable. They are instructed that:

  1. Medical therapy fails in at least 5–10% of cases. 
  2. If tubal rupture occurs (a 5–10% chance), emergency surgery is necessary.   
  3. If the woman is treated as an outpatient, rapid transportation must be reliably available. 
  4. Signs and symptoms of tubal rupture such as vaginal bleeding, abdominal and pleuritic pain, weakness, dizziness, or syncope must be reported promptly. 
  5. Until the ectopic pregnancy is resolved, sexual intercourse is prohibited, alcohol should be avoided, and folic acid supplements—including prenatal vitamins—should not be taken.

questions.text: A 1-week-old infant was brought in with a history of abdominal distension. Further history revealed absence of stool passage. Clinical evaluation revealed a diagnosis of Hirschprung’s disease. In Hirschsprung’s disease, aganglionic segment is:
questions.solution:
• Occurs in 1 out of every 5000 live birthsQ
  • MC affected site: Rectosigmoid (75%)Q >splenic flexure or transverse colon (17%) > Entire colon with variable extension into the small bowelQ (8%)
  • Increased Risk : Positive family historyQ and Down syndromeQ

Pathogenesis

  • Characterized pathologically by absent ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) and submucosal (Meissner’s) plexus with hypertrophy of nerve trunksQ in the plexus
  • Associated with muscular spasm of the distal colon and internal anal sphincter resulting in a functional obstructionQ
  • Abnormal bowel is the contracted distal segment, whereas the normal bowel is the proximal, dilated portionQ.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman G3P2 at 34 weeks of pregnancy has pain abdomen, uterine tenderness and bleeding per-vaginum. Her vitals are stable and has a regular fetal heart tracing. Which step of following is not required?
questions.solution:
• The above case history is suggestive of Placental abruption.
  • The definitive management is Termination of pregnancy along with resuscitation as early as possible due to increasing risk of maternal and fetal morbidity with time
  • Route of termination should be decided depending upon maternal and fetal condition, bishops score and other obstetrical indications favouring a vaginal or cesarian delivery.
  • So Tocolysis is not done for above mentioned case.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P0, at 39 weeks of gestation, presents in active labor. On pelvic examination, the fetal head is placed in such a position that the occiput is placed anteriorly, and is fully flexed. Which of the following is the most common engaging diameter of the fetal head in such a position?
questions.solution:
Option A : The occiput placed anteriorly, 45 degrees to left of midline of maternal pelvis is suggestive of LOA that is left occipito-anterior position. The most common attitude of head is flexion where in the engaging diameter is suboccipito-bregmatic.

Diameters Measurement In CM (Inches) Attitude Of The Head Presentation
1. Suboccipito-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete flexion Vertex
2. Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
3. Occipito-frontal 11.5 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
4. Mento-vertical 14 cm (5 ½”) Deflexed head/ military position Brow
5. Submento vertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
6.Submento-bregmatic 9.5 cm (3 ¾’’) Complete extension Face

Option B : Mentovertical diameter is 14 cm long and is engaged in brow presentation or deflexed head.

Option C : Sub-mentobregmatic diameter is 9.5 cm long and is engaged in completely extended head presenting as face.

Option D : Sternobregmatic is the engaging diameter in mento-posterior face presentation and does not deliver as it is around 17 cm.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with acute pancreatitis complaints of recurrent episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemoglobin of 5.8 gm/dL, requiring transfusions of red cell units. Gastroscopy showed diffuse fundal gastric varices but no esophageal varices. A CT scan showed liquefactive necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma and splenomegaly with diffuse varices around the gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligament. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Splenectomy

  • Acute pancreatitis causes splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery.
  • This aneurysm causes splenomegaly.
  • Splenomegaly causes gastric varices, mainly along the greater curvature of the stomach and fundus.
  • Left-sided portal hypertension is also called SINISTRAL hypertension.
  • The treatment of choice is Splenectomy.

Option B: Portocaval shunt

  • The portocaval shunt is an abnormal vein connecting the blood supply from the intestine to the vein that returns blood to the heart, bypassing the liver called shunting.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient has a problem with the spleen, so Splenectomy should be done.

Option C: Splenorenal shunt

  • This is the surgical process in which the splenic vein is detached from the portal vein and reattached to the left kidney vein, called the renal vein, to relieve pressure, causing a portal system shunt.

Option D: None of the above

  • Splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery cause splenomegaly due to acute pancreatitis, so splenectomy should be done.

questions.text: A 50 year old women was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has had recurrent vaginal candidiasis in the past 6 months. She also has a history of chronic hypertension, heart failure and has had recurrent pancreatitis due to alcohol abuse. She is abstinent from the past 1 year, does not smoke and does not take illicit drugs. She takes enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin and spironolactone. Her blood sugar is high despite of healthy diet and exercise. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Metformin is the drug of choice in this patient who is recently diagnosed with with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Incorrect answers

B) dapagliflozin is a sodium- glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor which works by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule and thus decrease blood glucose levels by increasing urinary excretion of glucose. SGLT-2 inhibitors increase the risk of Vulvovaginal candidiasis, and UTI’s. Therefore, they are not indicated in this patient who has a history of Vulvovaginal candidiasis.

C) Liraglutide is a GLP-1 analogue and these drugs can cause pancreatitis. Therefore, are not indicated in this patient with a history of recurrent pancreatitis

D)Pioglitazone belongs to the class thiazolidinediones and are not indicated in this patient with heart failure

Educational objective metformin is a first-line therapy in type 2 DM. Side effects of the drugs are considered before prescribing any medication.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the infectious ward in the department of internal medicine. You are seeing housekeeping staff disposing of the medical wastes without adequate protective equipment & are at risk of accidental needle stick injury. Which infections would cause the maximum chance of spread in accidental needle stick injury?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hepatitis B

  • Hepatitis B is spread when blood, semen, or other body fluids from a person infected with the virus enters the body of someone who is not infected.
  • This can happen through sexual contact, sharing needles, syringes, or other drug-injection equipment, or from mother to baby at birth.

Option B: HIV

  • HIV can be transmitted via the exchange of a variety of body fluids from infected people, such as blood, breast milk, semen and vaginal secretions. HIV can also be transmitted from a mother to her child during pregnancy and delivery.
  • But it has not had the maximum risk of transmission through needle stick injury.

Option C: Hepatitis C

  • The hepatitis C virus is usually spread when someone comes into contact with blood from an infected person. This can happen through
  • Sharing drug injection equipment.
  • Today, most people become infected with hepatitis C by sharing needles, syringes, or other equipment to prepare and inject drugs.

Option D: EBV

  • EBV spreads most commonly through bodily fluids, especially saliva.
  • However, EBV can also spread through blood and semen during sexual contact, transfusions, and organ transplantations.
  • EBV can be spread by using objects, such as a toothbrush or drinking glass, that an infected person recently used.

questions.text:
Assertion and reasoning-
Assertion- Barium contrast is contraindicated in bowel perforation.
Reason- Barium contrast agents may cause peritonitis if they leak into peritoneal space.

choices.text: Both the Assertion and the Reason are correct and the Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion.
The Assertion and the Reason are correct but the Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion.
OurAssertionis true but the Reason is false.
The statement of the Assertion is false but the Reason is true.

questions.solution: Barium contrast agents are not preferred in bowel perforation because of risk of peritonitis if they leak into peritoneal cavity. Low osmolar iodinated contrast agents are used in such cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient underwent total thyroidectomy. After surgery patient complained of inability to raise her voice pitch. The most likely cause is injury to:

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve givessensory supplyto the larynx andabove the level of true vocal cord.

  • All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx aresupplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid (which is supplied by superior laryngeal, which is a branch of external laryngeal nerve).
  • Since cricothyroid is a tensor of the VC, so theVC will be curved/bowed and floppy leading to weak and husky voice and inability to raise the pitch.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dysphagia and hematemesis. Dysphagia affects more solids than liquids. An endoscopic evaluation reveals a mass lesion in the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following options is most likely associated with tumorsof the gastroesophageal junction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Siewert type II

  • Siewert classification is a system of anatomical classification used for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction.
  • In type Siewert type II, Adenocarcinoma is present in the real cardia.
  • Its exact location is 1 cm above and 2 cm below the gastroesophageal junction.

Option A: Siewert type I

  • In Siewert type I, adenocarcinoma is present in the distal esophagus.
  • It is 1-5 cm above the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option C: Siewert type III

  • In Siewert type III, Adenocarcinoma is present in the Sub-Cardinal Stomach.
  • Its location is 2-5 cm below the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option D: Siewert type IV

  • This classification has only three types.

questions.text: A 58-year-old fisherman has been heavily exposed to the sun for more than 30 years. He develops a thickened, scaly lesion extending over two-thirds of the lower lip. There is no ulceration. Histology reveals hyperkeratosis. What should he undergo?

choices.text: Steroid ointment application three times daily
Lip stripping and resurfacing with mucosal advancement

questions.solution: Hyperkeratosis of the lip is a premalignant lesion and usually occurs in people exposed excessively to the sun. The mucosa undergoes metaplasia to keratosquamous epithelium. The lip becomes pale, thin, and fragile, with cracks and fissures, and is covered with a white base

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about insulinoma?

choices.text: Tumor of pancreatic β cells which results in overproduction of insulin and can cause hypoglycemia.
Symptomatic patients have low blood glucose and increased C-peptide levels.
More than 90 % of cases are associated with MEN 1 syndrome
Whipple triad: low blood glucose, symptoms of hypoglycemia (eg, lethargy, diplopia), and resolution of symptoms after normalization of glucose levels may be seen.

questions.solution:
(More than 90 % of cases are associated with MEN 1 syndrome)

Correct statement would be → ∼ 10% of cases associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

A, B and D are true about insulinoma. Therefore, are not the answer

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Insulinoma is the Tumor of pancreatic β cells which results in overproduction of insulin and causes hypoglycemia. May see Whipple triad: low blood glucose, symptoms of hypoglycemia (eg, lethargy, syncope, diplopia), and resolution of symptoms after normalization of glucose levels. Symptomatic patients have decreased blood glucose and Increased C-peptide levels (vs exogenous insulin use). ∼ 10% of cases associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

Treatment: surgical resection.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male worker was brought in to the emergency department by his company supervisor with a history of accidental amputation of right ring finger. After the first aid & stabilizing the patient, you are referring the patient to a higher center for plastic surgeon opinion & further management. The amputated finger is transported in:-
questions.solution: “if it is anticipated that the amputated part will be considered for replantation, it is critical to transport the patient and the part in an appropriate manner. The amputated part is placed in a clean, dry, plastic bag, which is sealed and placed on top of ice in a Styrofoam container. This keeps the part sufficiently cool at 4 degree C to 10 degree C without freezing. The amputated part is wrapped in a lightly moistened saline gauze to prevent tissue drying. (Schwartz 20/e p 1996)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with complaints of epigastric pain for 5 days came to our emergency department for help. Physical examination showed right lower quadrant tenderness without muscle guarding and rebounding pain. CT- abdomen showed suspect MD in the distal ileum and enteritis at the ileum. Which of the following is not a recognized complication of a Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the most common congenital abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract occurring in 2% of the population. It is an embryological remnant of the vitello-intestinal duct and is therefore found within 2 ft of the ileocaecal valve. The diverticulum varies in size in different individuals; large diverticula often have a fibrous cord (the remnant duct) linking them to the umbilicus.

The cells that line the vitello-intestinal duct are pluripotent and may therefore differentiate into any tissue. However, most commonly the diverticulum is lined with heterotrophic gastric epithelium (50%) or pancreatic tissue (5%). The most common clinical presentation of Meckel's is gastrointestinal haemorrhage secondary to peptic ulcer-ation of this abnormal gastric epithelium, which contains a pre-dominance of acid-secreting parietal cells. This is most commonly a childhood presentation causing melaena at around 10 years of age and accounts for over 50% of all symptomatic disease associated with Meckel's. The mucosa is also at risk of malignant change, most com-monly adenocarcinoma.

Meckel's diverticula are at risk of mechanical complications. Diver-ticulitis accounts for 20% of symptomatic presentations with features indistinguishable from acute appendicitis. The abnormal segment is also liable to cause intussusceptions following inversion into the ileum or volvulus caused by the small bowel twisting around on the fibrous band at the diverticulum apex. Other presentations include perforation and umbilical fistulation, which occurs when the entire vitello-­intestinal duct remains patent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman with a history of multiple spontaneous abortions is brought to the Obstetric ER for an urgent ultrasonography of the abdomen and pelvis. On questioning about the reason, she mentions about her 14 weeks of gestation. The accompanying husband reassures her about the last few ultrasonography’s, not revealing any viable fetuses, but the woman insists on getting another examination done. The intern posted in the ER examines her and reassures her about her non-pregnant state. She, in disbelief, breaks the glass of the ER entrance and leaves the premises angrily. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER:

(C) Pseudocyesis: The woman in the question has a false belief of being pregnant, due to the objective signs of amenorrhea, obesity, subjective sensation of fetal movement, breast enlargement, even labor pains. This phenomenon is termed as pseudocyesis. It is a type of delusional disorder, and it is best managed with anti-psychotics if reassurance does not work.

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

(A) Ekbom syndrome: It is a delusional disorder in which the affected individual believes of being infested by a parasite,

(B) Couvade syndrome: It is a disorder in which the partners of a pregnant female develop the same experience that their pregnant spouses have. It is also called as sympathy pregnancy. It has not been clinically classified yet.

(D) Cotard’s syndrome: It is a common delusion found in persons with major depressive episode. The affected individual believes that the parts of their body, or whole body is missing, or that they are soiling, dead or does not exist. It can also present as a monosymptomatic delusion where the primary treatment would be an antipsychotic agent.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Delusional disorders present in various themes, including persecution, litigious, grandiose, jealousy, and love. The treatment of choice for them includes use of an antipsychotic drug i.e. a Dopamine blocking agent.

questions.text: G2P1L1, diabetic pregnant lady with 32 weeks of pregnancy comes with a USG showing fetal weight of 3.11 Kg. The previous pregnancy was terminated by emergency LSCS for fetal distress. The best plan of action is:
questions.solution: The patient is a case of previous LSCS with big baby (already the weight at 32 weeks is 3.1 Kg; the normal weight at 32 weeks is 1.5–1.8 Kg). Induction of labor in a case of previous LSCS is usually avoided (increased risk of scar rupture) and trial of scar in case of big baby also increases the risk of scar rupture. So LSCS is the preferred modality of delivery in a case of previous LSCS with a big baby and patient not in labor. Now the question is when to do the LSCS ? In babies of diabetic mother, the lung maturity is delayed and so LSCS cannot be done at 36 weeks. But babies of diabetic mothers have one more risk, which is that of sudden IUFD at term (40 weeks). So the babies of diabetic mothers should be delivered (by LSCS in this case) between 38 and 39 weeks of gestation. If she is a patient without any previous scar on uterus and if the pelvis is adequate, then labor should be induced at 38–39 weeks.

questions.text: A 6 year old girl is brought to spine clinic by her parents. The patient on examination is revealed to have an abnormal sideways bend in the spine. The doctor wants to use a brace to correct the said condition. Which of the following CAN’T be used?
questions.solution:
All braces are used for scoliosis curve correction. ASH brave is used in thoracic vertebral collapse eg in trauma or in TB spine.

Learning Objectives : one should know what braces can be used for what condition. Out of a plethora or orthotics, a surgeon should make the best choice.

questions.text: A 31-year-old women who is lactating came to OPD 6 weeks after delivery, for checkup and to get advice for the contraception. Which of the following is not advised.
questions.solution: The pearl index for Norplant is 0.05,but requires surgery for implantation and removal. Norplant surgery requires motivation for surgery so it is not the best option .POP or the mini pills are the same things and can be given in this case. IUCD can be given because the uterus is well contracted and retention is best, which makes it the best choice for contraception after 6 weeks of delivery. COCP can lead to failure of lactation ,so they are avoided.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male tracheostomised patient, with portex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. Which of the following is best next step in the management?

choices.text: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube
Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

questions.solution:
Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube is best next step in the management in the above case

  • Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate is done to avoid the blockage.
  • Suction of the tube with saline can’t be used when there’s a complete obstruction.
  • Jet ventilation is done below the level of larynx, when we’re operating on the larynx.

questions.text: A 40 year old male came to emergency department due to bowel and bladder incontinence, and back pain that has been getting progressively worse over the last 5 days. He states that he have a burning and tingling sensation on feet and gradually it radiate to knees bilater.His vital signs are temperature is 97.4°F,respirations are 14/min,blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.Physical exam is notable for weak leg flexion bilaterally .Increased tone, spastic weakness , symmetric, Reflexes are brisk, with positive Babinski sign. For next step in management what would be the best?
questions.solution:
Transverse myelitis is a neurological disorder caused by inflammation of both sides of one section of the spinal cord. Damages the insulating material covering nerve cell fibers (myelin). Symptoms are sensory alterations, pain, weakness, autonomic dysfunction. Lumbar puncture demonstrate CSF pleocytosis and increased IgG index. High dose corticosteroids is first-line treatment. Those who are unresponsive to corticosteroids can do plasmapheresis. This patient is presenting with paraesthesia’s, pain, weakness, and urinary/bowel dysfunction suggesting a diagnosis of transverse myelitis. A STAT MRI is important as it can rule out other life-threatening diagnoses such as cauda equina/conus medullaris syndrome.

Choice A : Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are non-invasive tests that show how well the lungs are working. Best initial step in management in Guillain-Barre syndrome

Choice B :Diagnose muscle and bone disorders, such as bone tumors and fractures. Pinpoint the location of a tumor etc. CT scan is not sufficient for rule out transverse myelitis.

Choice C : Emergency surgery, Only after MRI we can rule out the condition. If it indicated in cauda equina syndrome , then emergency surgery can perform.

Choice D : Lumbar puncture: Neuroimaging has excluded a compressive etiology then lumbar puncture can perform.

Educational objective : pathologic heterogeneity can be primary- idiopathic or secondary-systemic autoimmune disease.it can be partial or complete effect on the spinal cord. Common etiology includes post-infectious condition, post-vaccination, systemic autoimmune disease, demyelinating disease, medications like sulfasalazine, TNF-α inhibitors. Transverse myelitis can affects any age.

questions.text: A patient complains of painless swelling over the face with difficulty in swallowing. The appearance of the face is as shown below. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Painless swelling usually points towards malignancy.
  • Among the given options Acute parotitis and Acute sialadenitis can be excluded because they both are a painful condition.
  • Angioedema of the face is characterized by the presence of swelling around the lips and around the oral cavity.
  • Hence the answer is cancer of the parotid gland
  • Among malignant tumors of the parotid gland, mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common followed by adenocystic carcinoma.

questions.text: A 28-years-old male patient with a past medical history of hematochezia, abdominal pain, reduced appetite and unintentional weight loss came to your clinic. Back then he was diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease. This time he presented with cutaneous ulceration with purple undermined edges in his left lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Pyoderma gangrenosum is characterized by cutaneous ulceration with purple undermined edges, it is secondary to heightened immunological reactivity, usually from another disease process, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, non Hodgkin’s lymphoma or Wegener’s granulomatosis. Ulcers generally respond to steroids; surgery is rarely indicated and may exacerbate the condition.

Choice A - Hidradenitis suppurativa. It is a follicular occlusion followed by folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora (usually Staphylococcus aureus and Propionibacterium acnes) culminates in chronic suppurative, painful skin abscesses, sinus tracts and scarring. It occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, commonly in axillae and groins.

Choice C - Impetigo. It a superficial infection of the skin with staphylococci, streptococci or both. It is highly infectious characterized by blisters that rupture and coalesce to form a honey - coloured crust and usually affects children.

Choice D - Erysipelas. It is a sharply demarcated streptococcal infection of the superficial lymphatics, usually associated with broken skin on the face. The affected area is erythematous and edematous.

Learning objective Pyoderma gangrenosum is characterized by cutaneous ulceration with purple undermined edges, it is secondary to heightened immunological reactivity, usually from another disease process, such as inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, non Hodgkin’s lymphoma or Wegener’s granulomatosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an important factor in the formation of cholesterol gallstones?

choices.text: An increase in bile salt concentration
Age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet play a role in the supersaturation of bile

questions.solution:
Option D: Age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet play a role in the supersaturation of bile

  • Supersaturation of secreted bile (lithogenic bile) - The primary event in the formation of cholesterol stones is the supersaturation of bile with cholesterol. 
  • Cholesterol is highly nonpolar, and its solubility in water and bile depends on the relative concentration of cholesterol, bile salts, and lecithin (the main phospholipid in bile). 
  • When cholesterol hypersecretion is present, supersaturation occurs, and cholesterol concentrations exceed the ability of the bile salts and phospholipids to maintain solubility; the cholesterol precipitates out of the solution into crystals. 
  • Age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet play a role in the supersaturation of bile.

Option A: An increase in bile salt concentration leads to increased solubility of cholesterol in bile, leading to stone formation

  • A decrease in bile salt concentration leads to decreased solubility of cholesterol in bile, leading to stone formation
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Progesterone-containing oral contraceptives can predispose to gallstone formation

  • Progesterone-containing oral contraceptives can predispose to gallstone formation.

Option C: Primary event in the formation of cholesterol stones is increased stasis in the gallbladder, allowing more time for solutes to precipitate in the gallbladder

  • Gallbladder dysmotility - Increases stasis in the gallbladder, allowing more time for solutes to precipitate in the gallbladder.
  • However, the primary event in the formation of cholesterol stones is the supersaturation of bile with cholesterol.

questions.text: A 25-years-old male visited the outpatient with the complaint of frequent urges to wash his hands repeatedly with a repeated thought that his hands were getting dirty. He was hesitant in resting his arms on the table or get his blood pressure monitored stating it might need him to take a bath again. He was concerned with his reduced productivity at work and frequent scolding from his boss due to the same. Despite his best efforts to control, he was unable to and it had increased since the last 6 months and he risked losing his job due to the same. He was not suffering from any other medical condition. No use of any recreational substance or drugs was noted in him. Which of the following medications would the person benefit from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Presence of a repeated intrusive thought suggestive of dirt and contamination with repeated hand washing behaviour which has increased for 6 months in the person suggests the diagnosis of Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Pharmacological management of OCD primarily involves selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI). Fluoxetine is an SSRI used in the management of OCD. So, the person would benefit from Fluoxetine.

Incorrect Answer: B, C, D

Explanation:

B) Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic used in the management of Schizophrenia. It is not used to treat OCD and can in fact increase the symptoms of OCD.

C) Trihexyphenidyl is an anti-muscarinic agent used in the management of Parkinson’s disease. It is not used to treat OCD.

D) Promethazine is a first generation anti histaminic with primary use in rhinitis, allergic reactions, anaphylaxis. It is also used as an injection via intramuscular route along with haloperidol to aid in sedation of acutely aggressive patients.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

OCD is diagnosed by Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents in the patient department with headaches and gait abnormalities. A fundoscopic examination is notable for bilateral papilledema. Sagittal MRI shows the lesion in the posterior aspect of the third ventricle that strongly enhances with gadolinium. Surgical excision is done, and histopathology confirms that the lesion is a pinealoma. What is the blood supply of the gland involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior choroidal arteries

  • The pineal gland, or epiphysis cerebri, is a small endocrine gland that produces melatonin, a serotonin-derived hormone.
  • Melatonin modulates sleep patterns in both circadian and seasonal cycles.
  • The pineal gland is not isolated from the body by the blood-brain barrier (BBB).
  • Pineal gland is present posterior to the midbrain, so if the tumour is in the pineal gland, it may lead to dorsal midbrain syndrome as it would press on the midbrain from behind.
  • The following diagram shows a calcified pineal gland.

  • It has profuse blood flow from the choroidal branches of the posterior cerebral artery.
  • Posterior cerebral artery is divided into three segments; P1, P2, and P3.
    • P1 supplies- Midbrain
    • P2 supplies - thalamus and temporal lobe
    • Post choroidal arteries supplies -Pineal gland
  • The branches of the posterior cerebral artery are known as central and cortical branches.

Central branches

  • Anterior and posterior thalamoperforator artery (arises from P1)
  • Thalamogeniculate artery (arises from P2)
  • Medial and lateral posterior choroidal artery (arises from P2)

Cortical branches

  • Anterior and posterior temporal artery
  • Medial and lateral occipital arteries
  • Parieto-occipital artery
  • Calcarine artery PCA (Posterior Cerebral Artery) P1, P2, and 10-11 Post choroidal arteries

Option B: Tuberothalamic artery

  • Tuberothalamic artery originates from the posterior communicating artery, which connects the vertebrobasilar and carotid systems.
  • It supplies the paramedian thalamic area.

Option C: Recurrent artery of Heubner

The recurrent artery of Heubner is a branch of the anterior cerebral artery.

  • It is also known together with the lenticulostriate arteries as a striate artery. The lenticulostriate arteries arise from the middle cerebral artery.
  • It supplies the anteromedial section of the caudate nucleus, the anteroinferior section of the internal capsule, and parts of the putamen and septal nuclei.

Option D: Lenticulostriate artery

  • The lenticulostriate arteries, also known as anterolateral central arteries, are a collection of small perforating arteries arising from the anterior part of the circle of Willis.
  • These arteries supply the basal ganglia.
  • They are divided into:
    • medial lenticulostriate arteries
    • lateral lenticulostriate arteries

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the anatomy of the respiratory system. They find that it is divided into various anatomical and physiological segments. They studied the lungs are divided into various lobes by various boundaries. They called the boundaries or separating lines lungs fissures. These fissures may be used to locate the disease and determine the lobe of the lung involved in the disease process. What is the structure marked in the lateral chest X-ray below?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A : Major fissure

  • A fissure is a normal cleft between body parts or in the substance of the organ.
  • Lungs are divided into various lobes by fissures. A fissure is a boundary between various lobes of the lungs.

  • A fissure is a double-layered enfolded invagination of the visceral pleura.
  • Major fissures separate the upper and lower lobe on the left side and the upper and middle lobes on the right side.
  • A major fissure is also known as an oblique fissure.

  • The left lung has an oblique fissure that divides the lungs into the upper and lower lobes.
  • The right lungs have two fissures (oblique and horizontal fissures). A horizontal fissure separates the right upper lobe from the right middle lobe.
  • Numerous accessory fissures are also present in the lungs.
  • The right lung has three lobes and two fissures, while the left has two lobes and one fissure.
  • The fissure helps in the uniform expansion of the lungs during respiration.
  • Fissures may be used to locate the disease and determine the lobe of the lung involved in the disease process.

Option B: Minor fissure

  • A horizontal fissure is also known as a minor fissure.
  • It is present in the right lungs and separates the right middle lobe from the right upper lobe.

 

Option C: Azygos fissure

  • Azygous fissure is caused by the right posterior cardinal vein failing to migrate over the right lung apex.
  • It is visible on the chest X-ray as the right paramediastinal supernumerary line.

​​​​​​

Option D: Transverse fissure

  • A transverse fissure overlies the fourth rib.
  • It meets an oblique fissure at the level of the mid-axillary line.
  • The transverse fissure results in three lobes on the right-side lungs.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A child presents with seborrheic dermatitis, sinusitis and chronically draining ears. On examination child has failure to thrive, with hepatosplenomegaly and exophthalmos, probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture prints to a diagnosis Langerhans cell Histiocytosis previously called Histiocytosis X.

  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome- hypopigmentation, frequent infections, ataxia
  • Retinoblastoma- intraocular tumor, leukocoria, strabismus
  • Wegener's granulomatosis- URTI, glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with dry cough, low-grade fever, malar rashes and shortness of breath. on physical examination there is notable swollen cervical Lymph node without access and fine inspiratory crackles. X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy without lung parenchymal involvement. laboratory results shows hypercalcemia and histopathological examination shows giant cell granuloma without caseation. According these investigation results what will be your diagnosis.?
questions.solution:
