Sarcoidosis is a autoimmune multisystem inflammatory disease most common in females age between 20-40years . deposition of sarcoid material anywhere in the body ,it affects multiple organs but more common in lungs (90%cases) and lymph nodes. The formation of granulomas(tiny clumps of inflammatory cells) in one or more organs of the body. Sarcoidosis is characterized by noncaseating granulomas. clinical presentations is low grade fever, Dry cough, weight loss, swollen cervical lymph nodes without abcess formation. Radiological evidence of Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hall mark of sarcoidosis . diagnostic criteria of sarcoidosis is CD4/CD8 ratio (3.5:1). Hypertrophied malar rashes is a specific sign of sarcoidosis.

Choice A : Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease. The production of unusual antibodies in the blood. Symptoms are Malar rashes, fatigue, fever, hair loss, rash, pulmonary problems, kidney problems, swollen joints, gastrointestinal problems, dry mouth and eyes.

Choice C: Emphysema : destruction of small airway at the acinus level . 2 types centri acinar and panacinar. most common in 70 years and above aged people. Symptoms: breathing hard to maintain O2 saturation, late cyanosis, pursed lip, pink puffer appearence of patient is thin and heart is thin and tubular because of inflated lungs .

Choice D :Scleroderma is an uncommon condition that results in hard, thickened areas of skin

Educational objective:

Sarcoidosis is usually occurs 20-40 years of age female are more common than male. African American are very prone to sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is triggered by body immune system responding to foreign substances like bacteria, virus or chemical. Mostly sarcoidosis is mis diagnosed as lymphoma because the granuloma looks like cancerous masses. Disease similar to sarcoidosis is cirrhosis, Alzheimer's disease, amyloidosis, copd etc.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came to the ENT OPD with a history of headache while waking up and gradually relieved towards the evening. Which of the following describes best about this headache?
questions.solution:
Office Headache: Headache on sunrise & relief at sunset is seen in Frontal sinusitis (Typical)

Periodicity is a characteristic feature in Frontal sinus infection

SITE OF TENDERNESS
Maxillary Cheek& Alveolus
Frontal Below eye brow (Office headache)
Ethmoid Medial canthus of eye
Sphenoid Vertex

questions.text: An 11-month-old infant is brought to the hospital outpatient department with complaints of an enlarged head, headache, vomiting, vertigo, and difficulty in straight walking for the past five months. On examination, persistent downward deviation of the eyes, papilledema, raised intraocular pressure, and abnormal gait is noted. Patient's head circumference > +3 SD. Diagnostic radiograph shows pathological abnormality. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hydrocephalus

  • Clinical signs of headache, vomiting, vertigo, raised intraocular pressure, and persistent downward deviation of the eyes suggest that it is most likely a case of hydrocephalus.
  • Hydrocephalus is an abnormal enlargement of cerebral ventricles or subarachnoid space due to excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) accumulation.
  • Two types of true hydrocephalus:
    • Communicating hydrocephalus occurs due to decreased CSF absorption or increased CSF production without any CSF-flow obstruction.
    • Non-communicating hydrocephalus occurs due to the obstructed passage of CSF from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space.
  • Both forms cause elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), which causes headache, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Investigations:
    • Ultrasonography: during the antenatal period or in infants < 6 months of age
    • Magnetic resonance imaging: patients > 6 months of age
    • Computed Tomography Scan: patients > 6 months of age
  • Treatment:
    • Most types of hydrocephalus are progressive and carry a risk of neurological damage. Definitive treatment of hydrocephalus involves the drainage of excessive CSF through the cerebral shunt. Usually, ventriculoperitoneal shunt.

Option B: Epidural hematoma

  • Epidural hematoma refers to bleeding between the dura mater and the calvarium.
  • Most cases of epidural hematoma (EDH) are traumatic, resulting from a head injury with an associated skull fracture that ruptures the middle meningeal artery.
  • EDH is more common in individuals 20–30 because the dura mater is not yet densely adherent to the calvarium at this age.

Option C: Intracerebral haemorrhage

  • Intracerebral haemorrhage refers to bleeding within the brain parenchyma.
  • Patients with Intracerebral bleeding are more likely to present with severe headaches and have rapidly progressing symptoms. The most significant risk factor for spontaneous intracerebral haemorrhage is arterial hypertension.
  • Symptoms are often nonspecific and depend on the affected vessel and cerebral region.

Option D: Macrocephaly

  • If an infant has macrocephaly, they have a head circumference much more extensive than another infant of the same age and sex.
  • A head circumference ≥ 2 standard deviations above the mean size for a given age and sex is usually ≥ 97th percentile.

questions.text: A 33-year-old G3P2L2 at 10 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding PV was diagnosed with molar pregnancy. She is advised to have hysterectomy done. The advantage of hysterectomy in molar pregnancy is?

choices.text: Enlarged ovaries can be removed during operation
Chance of pulmonary embolisation is minimal

questions.solution:
• Chance of choriocarcinoma may be reduced significantly but cannot be brought down to nil.
  • Follow up is mandatory and the lutein cyst should not be removed as a routine during surgery.
  • Chance of pulmonary embolisation is minimal

questions.text: A 45-years-old male was brought to the outpatient department of psychiatry by his brother saying he had become overtalkative again, was speaking grandiose and was predominantly cheerful. His activity levels had increased and he was sleeping just 3-4 hours daily since the last 1 week. He had become easily distractible and kept doing multiple tasks with no completion of any of the same. He had history of 4 such similar episodes in last 6 years and was on tab carbamazepine 600mg/d. He took his medications regularly and hadn’t missed any dose. He had been asymptomatic for the past 2.5years. His brother expressed concern regarding re-emergence of symptoms despite adhering to the prescribed dose of medications. On evaluation of serum carbamazepine level, it was found to be 3 mcg/ml. What could be the possible reason for the same?

choices.text: Auto induction of metabolism by carbamazepine.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

(B) Auto induction of metabolism by carbamazepine: The episodic course of illness with current episode characterised by cheerfulness, increased activity levels, grandiose talks, distractibility suggest bipolar affective disorder in the patient with current episode of mania. Carbamazepine is a mood stabilizer with the property of auto-induction of its own metabolism. As the serum level of carbamazepine in the patient was sub-therapeutic, possible explanation would be auto induction.

INCORRECT ANSWERS: A, C, D

.A) For tolerance to be a possible reason, the serum level of carbamazepine should be on therapeutic range (4-12 mcg/ml) but the patients serum drug level is 3 mcg/ml.

C) Adherence to treatment helps in prevention of further episodes and not precipitation of symptoms.

D) Good family support helps in adherence to treatment which helps in prevention of further episodes.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE: Mood stabilizers are the mainstay of pharmacotherapy in the maintenance phase of bipolar affective disorder. Carbamazepine is used as mood stabilizer, anti-epileptic and for trigeminal neuralgia. It is metabolised by CYP3A4. It has the property of auto induction i.e. it induces the enzyme CYP3A4 which is responsible for its own metabolism. Hence, the serum level can fall to sub therapeutic range requiring higher dose of medication.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the physician by his mother because of fever and pain in the left ear for the past 3 days. The mother states that he has repeatedly been rubbing his left ear since he woke up this morning. He has a history of atopic dermatitis, and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), his pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormality. Otoscopy of the patient is done. Below is the image of the patient's otoscopy. Which of the following statement below is true regarding patient's otoscopy?

choices.text: This is an image of the right tympanic membrane
This is an image of the left tympanic membrane
Umbo is not most visible landmark of the tympanic membrane
Posterior wall of EAC is deeper than the anterior wall

questions.solution:
Option A: This is an image of the right tympanic membrane

  • "This is an image of the right tympanic membrane" is a true statement because this is a picture of a normal right tympanic membrane as handle of the malleus starts at 1'o clock position, and the cone of light is at 5'o clock.

Option B: This is an image of the left tympanic membrane

  • This is a case of myringitis bullosa is a painful condition characterized by the formation of hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. It is probably caused by a virus or Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • This is an image of the left tympanic membrane.
  • Umbo- The most visible landmark of the tympanic membrane.
  • The anterior wall of EAC is deeper than the posterior wall.
  • These 3 are true statements according to this case.
  • This picture is of a normal left tympanic membrane as the handle of the malleus is at 11'0 clock, and the cone of light is at 7'0 clock.
  • Side identification of tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination:
    • The anterior wall of EAC is deeper than the posterior wall.
    • The handle of the malleus starts at 1'o clock position in the right and 11 o'clock position in the left ear.
    • The cone of light goes from umbo to 5'o clock position in the right ear and 7 o'clock position in the left ear.
    • Incus long process/ stapes super-structure if at all seen, they are in posterosuperior quadrant.

Option C: Umbo is not most visible landmark of the tympanic membrane

  • Umbo probably is the most visible landmark of  the tympanic membrane.
  • It help to differentiate the otoscopy of otitis media from otitis externa.

Option D: Posterior wall of EAC is deeper than the anterior wall

  • The anterior wall of EAC is deeper than the posterior wall.
  • The handle of the malleus starts at 1 o'clock position in the right and 11 o'clock position in the left ear.

questions.text: A child who is admitted in the IPD of pediatric dept. upon improvement in her health was making cooing sound and was laughing aloud. However, she was not able to sit. She was not able to engage in mirror play and did not have any stranger anxiety. While the senior doctor was taking a clinical class for the final year students, one of them asked the age of this child, and students were told to guess from the clue she was already showing while playing?
questions.solution:
A child laughs aloud at the age of 4 month.

  • 1 month → alerts to sound
  • 2 months → Vocalizes
  • 3 months → Coos
  • 4 months → Laughs aloud

Language milestone

Cooing 3 months
Laughs loudly 4 months
Monosyllables 6 months
Canonical Babbing (Ba-Da-Ma) 8-10 months
Bisyllables 9 months
1st read word 12 months
Jargon Speech 15 months

Personal social and cognitive milestones

Spontaneous smile Neonatal period
Recognizes mother 3 months
Hand regard Begins 12 weeks and ends at 20 weeks
Smiles at mirror image 5 months
Vocalises or jumps while looking at mirror image 6 months
Object permanence 9 months

Learning objective

Rules of Development

  • Continuous process, starting in utero
  • Sequence of attainment of milestones remains same
  • Depends on neurological status of child
  • Cephalo-caudal direction
  • Truncal development followed by limb development
  • Certain primitive reflexes have to be lost

questions.text: The patient presented with hoarseness following a protest. Endoscopy showed the following appearance. He should be managed by:
questions.solution:
Endoscopy shows vocal polyp

  • Vocal polyp happens due to a sudden voice abuse (e.g. shouting) usually by an unprepared larynx.
  • It is unilateral & present at the site of maximum vibration of vocal cords i.e. junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd (as can be seen in the endoscopic photo).
  • It has to be always excised by microlaryngeal surgery (MLS)

questions.text: A 12 year - old girl with corticosteroid and cyclophosphamid resistant nephritic syndrome presented with acute renal failure. According to pRIFLE criteria, renal failure is defined as urine output less than?
questions.solution:
pRIFLE criteria for renal failure:

Criteria Estimated creatinine clearance Urine output
Risk decrease by 25% <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 8 hr
Injury decrease by 50% <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 16 hr
Failure decrease by 75% or <35 mL/min/1.73 m2 <0.3 mL/kg/hr for 24 hr or anuric for 12 hr
Loss Persistent failure >4 wk
End - stage Persistent failure >3 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came to OPD with palpable mass in relation to the testis. On examination, the testis was enlarged and the mass was hard. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men age 20 to 40 years

Most patients present with testicular pain or a testicular mass. Respiratory symptoms, back pain, weight loss or gynecomastia may indicate metastatic disease. A testicular mass is considered malignant till proven otherwise

Standard initial workup includes scrotal ultrasound (diagnostic study of choice) and serum tumour markers ( alpha fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin and lactate dehydrogenase)

Most consider percutaneous biopsy contraindicated due to the rare but historical risk of disturbing the natural lymphatic drainage to the retro peritoneum and possible seeding of the scrotum

Radical inguinal orchiectomy (removal of testicle and scrotum at the level of inguinal ring) is the gold standard treatment for excision of the primary tumour

Right testicular cancer tends to metastasize to the interaortocaval lymph node, followed by paracaval and paraaortic lymph nodes. Left sided testicular cancer rarely crosses to the paracaval lymph nodes, they metastasize to the para aortic nodes and then interaortocaval nodes. Retroperitoneal lymph nodes are the primary metastatic site in more than 70% of patients with metastatic testicular cancer

Distant metastases are typically seen to the lung, liver, brain, bone, kidney and adrenal gland

Pure seminoma is radiosensitive; stages I, IIa and IIb disease can be treated with external beam radiation to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Alternatively, a single dose of carboplatin was found to be just as effective as radiation therapy

Stage I to IIA non seminomatous testis cancer is potentially cured with retroperitoneal lymph node dissection or chemotherapy

The overall prognosis is generally better for seminomatous than nonseminomatous germ cell tumours

questions.text:
A 52-year-old women comes to the emergency department due to pain and swelling in right leg since yesterday. Duplex ultrasound shows a right poplitial vein thrombosis. The patient is started on anticoagulation therapy and admitted to medical floor. On the fourth day of hospitalization right leg is more swollen and painful. Repeat USG was performed and it showed extention of the thrombus to the right femoral vein. Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin → 12.0 g/dL
Platelets → 40,000/mm3
leukocytes → 8000/mm3
aPTT → 80 seconds
Which of the following drugs was most likely used to treat this patient's DVT?
questions.solution:
This patient's markedly elevated aPTT is suggestive of unfractionated heparin use. This patient with thrombocytopenia, and thrombus progression 4 days into anticoagulation therapy likely has Type 2 heparin induced thrombocytopenia. Type 2 Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) occurs due to development of IgG antibodies against heparin_bound platelet factor 4 (PF4). Antibody-heparin-PF4 complex activates platelets and causes thrombosis and thrombocytopenia

INCORRECT ANSWERS:

B) Warfarin typically causes prothrombin time prolongation and does not affect platelet count.

C) The risk of Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is lower with enoxaparin than with unfractionated heparin

D) Argatroban is a Direct thrombin inhibitor and it is used in Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE : Type 2 Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) occurs due to development of IgG antibodies against heparin_bound platelet factor 4 (PF4). Antibody-heparin-PF4 complex activates platelets and causes thrombosis and thrombocytopenia. It should be suspected in patients recieving heparin who have thrombocytopenia, thrombosis , or a >50% drop in platelet count from baseline 5-10 days after initiation of treatment

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of worsening headaches, nausea, and vomiting for the past month.  In the past three days, they have noticed he has been "wobbly" when walking, losing his balance, and falling frequently. Examination shows a broad-based gait and difficulty with heel-to-toe walking. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals the following.. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Medulloblastoma

  • This patient presents with a medulloblastoma. This is the most common malignant brain tumour of childhood and is exclusively located within the cerebellum. It accounts for 20% of primary tumours of the central nervous system among children less than 19 years of age, and incidence peaks between the ages of 5 and 9 years.
  • Patients with medulloblastoma present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP ), such as morning headaches, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status, and cerebellar dysfunction, such as gait ataxia, truncal instability, and limb incoordination, depending on the tumour location.
  • Symptoms typically develop over a period of weeks to months and begin with those associated with raised ICP before those due to growth and invasion of the tumour within the cerebellum. Diplopia and dizziness may also result from the involvement of the cerebellum, brainstem, or cranial nerves.

Option B: Pilocytic astrocytoma

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are the most common primary brain tumour in childhood. They are well-circumscribed cystic tumours, often arising within the cerebellar hemispheres. Due to their slow-growing nature, symptoms usually develop over the years. When cysts are present in medulloblastomas, they are typically small and multiple rather than large solitary cysts.

Option C: Brainstem glioma

  • Brainstem gliomas arise in the midbrain, pons, or medulla and account for 10-20% of central nervous system tumours in children. Most patients have a relatively long history of minor symptoms, which may have been present for over a decade.

Option D: Atypical teratoid

  • Atypical teratoid also known as rhabdoid tumours are rare, highly malignant tumours primarily occurring in children less than three years of age. Two-thirds occur within the cerebellum, symptoms are location-dependent, and the prognosis is poor.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain. ECG showed findings of ventricular fibrillation. All are true about steps followed in management of ventricular fibrillation except?

choices.text: Start CPR followed by immediate defibrillation
Intravenous access followed by Immediate defibrillation

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came to ENT OPD with a complaint of giddiness while waking up from the bed. The patient developed nystagmus in Dix-hallpike maneuver. Which of the following is most commonly involved in this case?
questions.solution:
• Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position.
  • There is no hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms.
  • Positional testing establishes the diagnosis and helps to differentiate it from positional vertigo of central origin.
  • BPPV most commonly arises from the posterior semicircular canal. Much less frequently the horizontal semicircular canal

questions.text: 14 A patients come in ER after sustaining a fall. The hip is in abduction and external rotation position. The x-rays confirm posterior dislocation of the hip. Which of the following is NOT a manoeuvre for reducing a dislocated hip?
questions.solution: Learning objective: The surgeon must be aware of all methods of reduction of a hip. Some method need one assistant some need two. So methods should be known as personnel in the hospital may or may not be of the required number.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male, alcoholic is a known cause of chronic pancreatitis. He presented with features consistent with obstructive jaundice. Which of the following is the most common cause of obstructive jaundice in such patients with chronic pancreatitis?

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas
Fibrotic stricture of the common bile duct

questions.solution: Biliary complications involving the common bile duct can occur in chronic pancreatitis because of the intimate association of that structure with the head of the pancreas. In two-thirds of individuals, the common bile duct traverses the pancreatic parenchyma and in an additional 25%, the common bile duct lies within a groove along the posterior surface of the pancreas. Fibrosis associated with chronic pancreatitis can encase and compress the common bile duct. Common bile duct stenosis is relatively common in chronic pancreatitis, occurring in approximately 10% of cases observed long-term. Cholangiography typically reveals a long, gradually tapering stricture conforming to the intrapancreatic portion of the common bile duct. In contrast, malignant strictures usually result in abrupt termination of the biliary duct. The proximal suprapancreatic portion of the bile duct is variably dilated.
